When contemplative capo regime Caspar, played memorably by Jon Polito, discovers a bookie (Turturro) is chiseling-in on his fight fixing scheme but fails to elicit a punitive response from the biased boss, the family man goes to war (scenes with his son {Mounicou} are incredible). And keep your eyes peeled for an early, uncredited Frances McDormand performance as the Mayor's nonchalant secretary: AA: "Where ya' been keeping' yourself? Tommy: Hither & yon." Millers has the same addictive violence as GoodFellas but the better story, more developed characters, displays its own rich, Depression-era imagery, a terrific score (Burwell) and most important to the Classics, made sentiment its central emotion through friendship, loyalty & love, all moving it nearer to perfection. Both uncommon class, I call Crossing the winner by a nose (4/4).

reviews.review_title: This reminded me not so much of The Godfather as Bugsy Malone.
reviews.content: I'm no fan of the popular tradition of American movies that glorify 'Godfather' style, extreme violence in the name of 'family' or in the name of 'bringing peace' or revenge or anything really. Simply excuses for loss of sentimentality and shooting. This one, though, I remember enjoying on its theatrical release and although again not a particular fan of the Coen Brothers reckoned that this early one would be fine. Its crap. From the very beginning my back is up. The Italian, Jewish et al stereotypes are up and running from the start and the 'oh so clever' dialogue that must have had the brothers curling up as they wrote it comes out the mouths of the over actors as bilge. This reminded me not so much of The Godfather as Bugsy Malone.

It's a theatrical canvas of film noir and gangster displayed before once eyes. I've seen this movie at least ten times and I still find it intriguing, beautiful and bitter at the same time.It's no secret it's made with clichés and an all to gritty dialouge, and that what's make it beautiful.It's a bootlegger paradise and anyone romantic about the 1920's has got to love this.Lines like: "He's still an artist with the Thompson" and "Maybe we can have tea some day." Is probably lines never said outside the world of movies and old Dashiell Hammet novels but it still works.And it has everything what one can want, Irish, Italian and Jewish gangsters, an imbecile boxer, a femme fatale, a plethora of costume and paraphernalia that just shines in every scene.The humor and the horror is equally present and makes this one for all breeds.SPOILERS: And to add to the classic setting of a fantasy, gangster cityscape it probably contains two of the most sadistic, horrible shoot outs in my regards. Albert Finney turning the Italian hit-man into lead-pie, a killing that never seems to end, suspended in time and than the army of police men turning the Irish Club Erin into Masada acts cayenne to this stew of pleasurable viewing.In my regards one of the best Coen-flicks and gangster movies

This is one of my most favorite gangster films. A neo-noir crime classic, with really cool performances by all the leads, including some scene stealing from Turturro and Polito. The narrative moves along at a nice pace, with only occasional or brief stalls.

reviews.review_title: The Coens pay homage to the American gangster movie
reviews.content: Millers Crossing is the Coen brother's take on the classic prohibition era gangster movie and it has many of the hallmarks of their unique style.The story is simple and quite clichéd really. The Irish American crime boss Leo (Albert Finney) has the authorities in his pocket as he runs his empire smoothly. However there is trouble on the horizon as one of the smaller gang leaders Johnny Caspar (Jon Polito) wants his permission to kill a crooked bookie Bernie Bernbaum (John Turturro). However Finney is in love with Turturro's sister (Marcia Gay Harden) and refuses.The film is told from the point of view of Finney's trusted lieutenant, Tom Reagan, played by Gabriel Byrne. He advises Finney not to let personal feelings impact on business decisions, but to no avail and things spiral out of control.The film is full of the double crossing and violence you would expect from an old-fashioned gangster movie. However the distinctive Coen style is what sets it apart. They pay homage to the great gangster movies of the past rather than telling a gangster story per se. There are some great set piece scenes, almost cartoonish violence and razor sharp dialogue. The costumes and sets are perfect in helping to bring us back to the golden age of gangster movies.The Coens seem more interested in style at the expense of character development so the cast don't have to display their undoubted talents. However Turturro is worthy of special mention for his turn as the sleazy bookie. I thought Byrne's Tom Regan comes across as a wisecracking know-it-all and I found it hard to have much sympathy with him. I found the other characters more appealing, for all their faults.I hadn't seen this film in a while and was perhaps expecting too much but it is still one of the landmark movies in the careers of these geniuses of modern cinema.

In this bubbling Coen gangster story, Gabriel Byrne plays heartless hit-man Tom Reagan who struggles to keep the peace between his Irish boss Leo and the rival Italian boss Caspar. In the seedy 1930's prohibition and depression era setting, people are both morally and economically bankrupt  which means a whole lot of violence, hard-boiled jargon and complex relations that can set off the balance of an uneasy peace.Miller's Crossing successfully combines the gritty gangster tone of 1930's with the glossy noir of the 1940s, creating a film so sprawling with contemporary crime surges that every scene acts as an invitation to soak up the wonderful atmosphere. With all of its hard-edged gangsters and its token femme fatale (Marcia Gay Harden, a dutiful Coen inclusion), it becomes a downright pastiche of the morally corrupt underworld that so many directors have recreated in previous decades. It needs to be said that Coens greatly prefer individual scenes to continuity and as a result, the already dizzying plot becomes more difficult to follow. Names like 'Mink', 'Leo', 'Caspar' and 'Bernie' snapple and crackle like kindling in a fireplace. The audience is left befuddled at the mess but arguably this is a large part of Miller's Crossing's appeal  it offers a big slice of the era rather than a well-sketched story.The acting, by contrast, is simply top-notch. Gabriel Byrne brings calculating intensity to Tom Reagan, John Turturro goes the extra mile and gives an unspeakably emotive performance as he prays of his life and Albert Finney is amazingly hard-edged and no-nonsense as crime boss Leo. Together the triumvirate of skilled actors  along with a wide-ranging cast of mandatory Coen actors  blow smoke, down whisky, gamble, cheat, fix and beat up every chance they get. The dialogue between them is compelling, fluent and viciously quotable with token 30's expressions like "chewing the fat" that form part of the love letter to the depression era.Miller's Crossing in its entirety boasts of no mindblowing appeal and it is mostly talk and little action. Dissecting its individual parts, however, and it becomes a truly great film with scenes so memorable and poignant that it floors you. The warehouse chair fight. Albert Finney defending himself in his own house with a machine gun. John Turturro kneeling and begging for his life. Tom's ominous hat flowing off. This is Coen in his element and if you are even a slight fan of the latter I urge you to see Miller's Crossing.7.5 out of 10

I've been trying to catch up on the Coen Brothers movies that I missed, and this one was a real disappointment.It felt like a film that didn't know what it wanted to achieve. The over-complex plot lacked credibility, with the main characters behaving in such a dim-witted manner that they'd never have survived a day in the world of crime, let alone risen to the top. A lot of the violence is exaggerated, with a cartoon-like quality. As a result, the movie lacked any real dramatic tension. Perhaps the film was intended to be a pastiche, but it didn't work for me on that level either.The lead character, Tom Regan, spoke all his lines in a laconic monotone which became very irritating very quickly. It was also never clear why the gangland bosses valued his contributions so highly, or his lady-friend found him attractive.The dialogue between the characters was always very arch and snappy, but this had the effect of nullifying any impetus to develop our understanding of them as real people. The relentless nature of the script seemed to overwhelm the movie, rather than contribute any real energy.I don't think I've seen a movie where so much effort and indeed talent has been wasted. It is so much less than the sum of its parts, though I suspect it may be those parts, taken in isolation, that may impress some punters. Each to his own, of course.

I don't care what that random person said before. This movie is brilliant. All you have to do is see the credits with the hat rolling and you can tell how great this film would be. The characters are amazingly strong and very human. It isn't very violent and when there is violence, it is realistic and brutal. This is a great film and everyone should see it. Definitely.Everyone I've spoken to loves this film, it is great The music is fantastic and so is everything else. The greatest scene is movie history ( one of the greatest ) is Albert Finney strolling down his street, in his dressing gown, shooting with a Tommy Gun to the tune of Danny Boy. It is fantastic

reviews.review_title: Joel and Ethan, I love these guys!
reviews.content: How do they do it?  How do these two guys get such talent and get it to work, time after time?  Amazing?  You bet.  Hey, even their dogs, e.g., "The Hudsucker Proxy," are great.  [I'm still mystified that some people didn't like Raising Arizona]  But, this film, dark, moody, sparked by stellar performances by Finney, Bryne, Turturro, Buscemi and of course, the lovely Marcia Gay Harden.  The comments here have touched on the many fine points that make this a paragon of the genre of film noir but let just say something about the music.  Carter Burwell, who has done a number of things with the Coens has outdone himself.  The opening credits begin with an oboe solo playing the haunting traditional Irish theme Limerick Lament which is spliced in several places throughout the film and then returns as the final credits role.  Now, as an oboist and fanatic fan of traditional Irish music, I was taken in from the start.  But, Burwell's other pieces and arrangements work so well with the whole film.  The soundtrack CD is fantastic.  This whole effort on the part of these brothers who have never disappointed me yet is utterly awesome.

'Miller's Crossing' is a cleverly constructed and sharply written piece of work in which the dialogue plays as important a role as the action in creating the drama. It is seemingly the tale of an amoral existentialist hero, Tom Reagan, negotiating his way through a complex situation, rather in the manner of a Jean-Pierre Melville film such as 'Le Doulos' or 'Le Samourai'. However the film is deeply concerned with questions of loyalty and obligation, and Tom's final choice is actually moral one. The film is carefully shot in an autumnal palate but is staged without extravagance and makes excellent use of the interior sets and few locations. The tight structure and deliberate air of unreality, which is heightened by deft comic touches, separates this from more portentous crime dramas such as 'The Godfather' or 'Once upon a time in America', and gives 'Miller's Crossing' its own unique place in the genre.

This film was very much a disappointment. I understand that it's meant to understated, but it's so subtle to the point of being droll. The first 45 minutes are quite confusing, there's lots of subtle plot points that seem to detract from the main plot. The acting is decent, but the script is borderline comically unrealistic without being ironic. Watching this movie, I wasn't sure if this was supposed to be a comedy, a gangster movie, or a drama. At times, it's all three and can't figure itself out. Gabriel Byrne's performance was underwhelming. He looked as bored as I was watching this movie. The characters are all unlikeable. By the end, you want them all to die. Only pretentious, faux-intellectual, artsy types would like this film. I'm generally a Coen Brothers fan, but this movie made me very angry watching it, mainly because I wasted two hours of my life. I would better have spent it watching Raising Arizona, Fargo, or The Big Lebowski even though I've seen them 100 times. The pace is extremely slow. This movie is all style and no substance. Nice art direction, nice cinematography, even good acting, but absurd script, excruciatingly slow pace, poor character development (what are there motivations?) and a plot spread thin over two hours complicated by unnecessary verbose dialog and distracting side bar sub-plots.

MILLER'S CROSSING is an ambitious outing from the Coen Brothers, considering their previous credits included a low-budget Noir (BLOOD SIMPLE) and a hysterically ridiculous comedy (RAISING ARIZONA).  This film truly put them on the map of fans and critics alike on a broad scale.  They also did an ingenious job of casting by bringing the always interesting Albert Finney on to play the head of the Irish mob, Leo.  MILLER'S CROSSING is another mob movie from 1990, the year of the mob come-back with GOODFELLAS and THE GRIFTERS.  This one is shot in beautiful period style (1930's) and has some of the best nicknames of mafia henchmen in the history of the genre. Sometimes, the nicknames can lead to confusion as to who the characters are discussing or how the plot is evolving.  When you have a "Caspar" and the "Dane" mixing with "Leo", "Tic-Tac", and "Mink", you tend to lose some dialogue along the way.  However, the Coens have created a wonderfully original world and use a blowing hat to symbolize the film's most important plot elements.Barry Sonnenfeld is back to shoot with the Coens and adds to his ever-growing list of good-looking films.  It is no wonder he became a talented director later on with MEN IN BLACK and GET SHORTY.  If you notice, whenever a character is not wearing their always treasured hat, they are at their most vulnerable.  John Turturro, as the sad-sack gambler "Bernie", pleads for his life in the woods, bloody and hatless.  Miller's Crossing is where the mobsters take their unwanted prey and properly dispose of them. Some very suspenseful scenes occur in the innocent greenlands of these woods.  At one point, Gabriel Byrne (in a crass, wiseguy role) is walking towards possible doom at the Crossing when he looks up at the trees.  They signify nature and how disastrous and evil events can happen under the most simplest pieces of life.A blowing hat is the keystone of the film's title sequence.  It blows innocently away and, in essence, leads us into the underworld the Coens have created.  An awesome shoot-out scene with Finney is incredibly well-done. It all happens so fast you long for it to go on.  Finney does some pretty acrobatic things and appears impenetrable as he just follows his would-be assassins with a blaring tommy-gun.  Many shocking scenes of violence play out and pay off by film's end, a nod towards the famous ending of THE THIRD MAN. Joseph Cotten had his hat on when he lost out on life and simply tosses his cigarette in disgust in THIRD MAN.  MILLER'S CROSSING is more of a character study of the Gabriel Byrne character, because when you think about it, the story does indeed revolve around his questionable actions.  It is a good performance amongst some beautiful sets and old cars that echo, yet again, a time that seemed more innocent, but was just as bloody and reckless as society now.  If only it could be as bloodless as the blowing hat.

The Coen Brothers pay homage to the gangster film and succeed for the most part. The opening scene, somewhat reminiscent of the opening of "The Godfather," sets the stage for the mob wars as rival gangs seek to take control of the underworld. Although the plot seems somewhat convoluted initially, it comes into focus after a while. The period (1930s) is recreated with all the right details and is helped by an evocative score. Byrne has perhaps the role of his career as the low-key gangster who is torn about his allegiances. Polito and Finney are quite good as rival crime bosses while Freeman makes a mean henchman.

I saw this film just one time on HBO about 14 years ago and I can't really say I remember every detail of the plot...but it is filled with some scenes that will probably stay with me till the day I die.Specifically I mean those scenes that take place in the woods! John Turturro was simply unforgettable in his big march into the woods scene as he perfectly personified every person's ultimate desperation and Gabriel Byrne almost matched his desperation when he had to prove he had actually carried out his orders. I'll never forget this film because no other two scenes have ever caused my heart to pound so loudly in my ears like that!

reviews.review_title: A fine addition to the Gangster genre
reviews.content: The Coen's brought us a fine addition to the gangster genre. Though it's not 100% your prototypical gangster movie, it's a fine fit with the Coen brothers' touch added. The movie had a nice look and feel to it and I really enjoyed watching the characters interact. In particular, I thought Gabriel Byrne's performance was outstanding. His style gave the film a bit of a noir-ish touch. If you're a fan of the genre or the Coen brothers, I think you'll enjoy Miller's Crossing.***1/2 (Out of 4)

reviews.review_title: Awesome Plotting; Possibly The Coen's Cleverest
reviews.content: Undoubtedly one of the great contemporary noir exercises, MILLER'S CROSSING is a highly potent and quixotic mix of grossly exaggerated caricatures and subtly underplayed winks. The storyline is remarkably adept at confounding expectations while still playing basically fair with the facts, which is high praise, given the state of modern cinema. The production values are high, the cinematography is solid, the dialogue crackles, the red herrings abound, and there is sex and violence aplenty (including a raging love triangle between the two goodguys and a hooker, no less).And yet...this is still one coldblooded and convoluted Coen Bros. effort. There is not a single character who isn't working all the angles and there's quite a bit to track. Gabriel Byrne in particular is confoundingly inscrutable; we're never quite sure whose side he's on which makes the rooting interests confusing. Albert Finney is winning and likable in a flashy but over the top mafioso role. Marcia Gay Harden also shines as the hooker with a heart of hot lead. Jon Polito is hilarious and completely hamfisted as the man constantly being given "the high hat." In the end, though, John Turturro steals the proceedings with his amazingly slithery and greasy portrayal of the ever adaptable Bernie Bernbaum. Turturro has the benefit of a great part in a great script and he makes the most of it. Still, with all of the triple crosses, it took two viewings for me to figure everything out and I suspect most might benefit from a second look. It's a bit confusing to sort.The overall result is an amazingly well-conceived script. Every main character is integral to the story and the Coen Bros. economy in their utilization and integration has never been better. Cold, dense and complex, MILLER's CROSSING is probably among the best three or four plotted noirs in the last quarter century. If you don't have patience for the cognitive dissonance in movies like MEMENTO or MULHOLLAND DRIVE, you may want to pass on this one. However, if you're a fan of this kind of pulpy noir / crime drama, this movie is a must see and one you'll probably review again shortly thereafter. 9.5 / 10

reviews.review_title: Coen & Coen and a just & upright cast and crew well worth your time.
reviews.content: Definitely at the outset a thank you kindly for such a well told story involving social perception and morality changing over time while cardinal virtues touching upon prudence fortitude temperance and justice forever being revisited in filmmaking such as this film exemplifies. Persuading fellows is one thing and imposing your views on another is a gamble. The smartest and those strongest in tongue and heart survive. Glimpsing unnecessary strikes upon a child while taking odds that favor one individual as opposed to a thematic emphasis in the script is played well by all the actors in each and every scene. 32 years ago and feeling what I felt then and feeling the same now definitely caused me to write about it once again because the movie stood for something worthy of notice. As you see fit. SMIB 2022.

I don't know if I watched this during a period where I was watching some of the best, highest acclaimed film's of all time, but something about this movie just rubbed me the wrong way as most of the Coen movies do.The setting and the theme are much better than the end results plotwise and this movie just shouts "Too-Long."Overall it's pretty decent, just nowhere near Godfather 1/2 or even Friends of Eddie Coyle greatness....

Most gangster movies put the violence and the sinful or unlawful behaviour of the characters in the foreground, making them, at best, culturally interesting. This one presents the reasoning and clockwork behind the criminal organisations during the prohibition period and puts a modern character in lead.Basic plot is that a counselor to a gangster is playing things so that they fall how he wants them, in a terrible game of chess, where people are pieces and they die. The best part is that in this game of chess, he is merely a pawn, but he topples kings.Bottom line: this film was destined to be a classic. It is all about the brains and keeping it cool in the face of chance and brute force. Gabriel Byrne makes a great role as does, as expected, John Turturo. Without it being an overly complex movie, you need to be in a cinema mood to really enjoy it to the fullest.

reviews.review_title: Miller's Crossing: A reality in three steps
reviews.content: Ethan and Joel Coen gave the world a masterpiece in 1990. This is pure perfection. Perfect casting. And the lead, Gabriel Byrne, did a great performance as the realistic, cynical but yet sympathetic Tom.To be a total masterpiece, you need a good start. I didn't like the start the first time I saw Miller's Crossing, but I changed my mind the second time I saw it. Just the great first picture with the ice falling into the glass ...'Miller's Crossing' is not a common crime-movie. It has elements of film noir and mobster-movies from the first generation (1930's) rather than from the second generation (1970's). The Coen-brothers doesn't try to hide that they have been inspired by the novels of Dashiell Hammett. For the first time, a movie filled with different important characters works perfect. I could understand the complicated relationships between all the people, and because I did, 'Miller's Crossing' became amazing. Everything seems so realistic but yet twisted, which is the greatness with 'Miller's Crossing'. It is so unpredictable and unconventional at the same time. And I also think that Coen by purpose filmed it in colors that looked like the old Technicolor from the 50's.Warning: SPOILERS AHEAD In the end, if you have understand, everything becomes clear in a weird way. Tom lefts Leo, but what does he plan to do? I don't think he becomes a happy man, and it is possible that he is afraid ... of chasing his own hat. Otherwise that is something he already managed to do before the plot in the film started ...Rating: 10 of 10.

The rumpus is that this is a technically perfect film that never got the respect it deserves, except perhaps from students of film. While every aspect of the production is first-rate, it is the editing that pops. From the first frame to the last, almost two hours of run-time, the viewer never sees or feels a break in the story, or in the continuity. That is the sort of smooth exposition you expect in a documentary, but is so rare in a drama. On paper, this is a simple story about about crosses, double crosses and triple crosses. But the story does not do justice to the experience. Extraordinary film-making. ((Designated "IMDb Top Reviewer." Please check out my list "167+ Nearly-Perfect Movies (with the occasional Anime or TV miniseries) you can/should see again and again (1932 to the present))

reviews.review_title: One of the greatest, and the best Coen film. Short review with a big spoiler.
reviews.content: Overall, Miller's Crossing is just a great cinematic experience. Everything from the acting to the writing to the cinematography is downright perfect. Gabriel Byrne, as always, is a treat to watch, and here he is a tongue-in-cheek type of gangster who almost seems to smirk his way through life, but he's tough as well. John Turturro becomes the epitome of what a supporting actor should be by almost stealing the show with a searing performance. Then you have some fantastic other roles played by Marcia Gay Harden, the always charismatic Jon Polito, and Albert Finney to add icing to an already delicious cake. The Coen writing shines here with a brilliant story about a conflicted gangster in the particularly vicious town of Miller's Crossing during the Prohibition era. The brutality is great, and you feel like you're in that same world with Al Capone, and all the other famous gangsters of the first several decades in the 1900s. Highlight of this film for me is definitely the twist when we're waiting to see how Tom Reagan (Gabriel Byrne) is going to get out of his precarious situation after having let Bernie (John Turturro) go earlier on. It was supremely tense for me, and I could feel Tom's relief after they find some other dead body lying in the woods, as we're left in a similar state of disbelief like he is. Great, great writing; I can't say it enough.I purchased Miller's Crossing years ago simply because I was a fan of the Coen brothers' work, and I had never seen it before then. I do not regret the decision, as each time I watch the film, I'm reminded why the Coens are some of the best filmmakers of their generation. 10 out of 10 stars.

I've been on the fence about this one because on the one hand I tend to find the Coen brothers' "genre films" less interesting than their genre-crossing films (admittedly the distinction is vague to non-existent, but I feel like True Grit is Coens doing western, something like Intolerable Cruelty is them doing romcom and this is them doing a gangster film, whereas movies like The Big Lebowski and O Brother, Where Art Thou? find them doing more of their own thing), but on the other hand, they again and again prove that they can master every genre they take on, and perhaps none better than Miller's Crossing's gangster film. Here, the brooding mood and the dryly humorous dialogue really shine, and Gabriel Byrne's amazing character is so hard-boiled and taciturn that he would fit just as well in a noir. He rarely speaks, but when he does, he seems to be little concerned with whether or not his comment will result in a punch in the face; in fact, the way he gets slapped around becomes a running gag of sorts.The opening reference to The Godfather suggests that we're in for a traditional gangster fare, but as often with the Coens, they strike a balance between homage and subversion by exploring themes beyond the surface plot. Here, they use the amoral American prohibition-era setting to delve into questions of morality in a more philosophical way than other gangster films (that might sound a little pretentious but the film is anything but) – what place it has within the world of crime, and where our moral decisions take us. Ethics is "what separates us from the animals", Johnny Caspar (played by a sleazier-than-ever (perhaps bar Coens' own The Man Who Wasn't There) Jon Polito) speculates, an interesting hypothesis that sheds little light on how the intricate relations of Miller's Crossing will play out, but we do learn that the line of separation is thin and vague. A more straightforward question is raised by Caspar later in the film: "you double-cross once, where's it all end?" Miller's Crossing ends when there's no one left to cross.

This may be my favorite movie of all time. It's definitely my favorite Cohen Brothers movies.I'm not going to say much about this other than watch the hats. Hats are a major symbol of power. Whoever is wearing the hat has the power, and this especially true in the Danny Boy scene. Leo isn't wearing a hat, but he seems to be winning the battle. Is he really?The time you really want to pay attention to a symbol is when it seems to be functioning against the way it had functioned previously.

I have always enjoyed watching the Coen Brothers' movies... Most movies they've made have had great stories, a great entertainment value clubbed with fabulous performances."Miller's Crossing" is no different. In fact, this could be my #1 Coen Brothers' movie if I were to rank them."Miller's Crossing" tells the story of two rival Mob bosses, Leo (Albert Finney) and Johnny Caspar (Jon Polito) and Leo's most trusted adviser, Tom Reagan (Gabriel Byrne). Things take a turn for the worse when Leo refuses to comply with Caspar about getting rid of one bookie who he feels has been cheating him. The story continues and what follows is a thrilling tale of double-cross and shifting loyalties.Right from the opening sequence ("I'm talking' about friendship...."), in which the brilliant Jon Polito as Johnny Caspar is relating his problem to Leo (Finney), this film makes an impression and it is immediately clear that the rest of the film is going to be just as impressive!The performances are all top-notch, including John Turturro, Gabriel Byrne, Albert Finney, Jon Polito and J.E. Freeman. Marcia Gay Harden is decent as well.On the technical front, cinematography by Barry Sonnenfeld is superb...so is the haunting musical score by Carter Burwell. The film has been edited really well. The dialogs are superb and well-written! And of course, let's not forget Joel Coen's brilliant direction."Miller's Crossing" is a fine gangster film, not to be missed by any respectable movie buff and deserves to be ranked amongst the best gangster movies of all time.

I knew this was a gangster movie, but I didn't know, or just forgot, that it was directed by brothers Joel and Ethan Coen (Fargo, No Country for Old Men, True Grit), so it would be interesting to see how they do with this specific genre. Basically set in Prohibition era 1930s, Tom Reagan (Gabriel Byrne) is the adviser and right hand man for Irish mobster and political boss Leo O'Bannon (Albert Finney). Italian racketeer and Leo's partner Johnny Caspar (Jon Polito) announces his intent to kill bookie Bernie Bernbaum (Quiz Show's John Turturro), against Tom's advice he extends his protection to Bernie, Verna Bernbaum (Pollock's Marcia Gay Harden) is Bernie's brother, she is in a relationship with Leo, but continues an affair with Tom. To end the war, Tom tries to convince Leo to give up Bernie to Caspar, he attempts to convince him he is being played by Verna to protect her brother, but Leo is not swayed, and after an assassination attempt on Leo, Tom reveals his affair with Verna to prove her dishonesty, Leo only beats her and turns his back on them both. Tom approaches Caspar for work, to prove his loyalty Caspar commands him to kill Bernie at Miller's Crossing, Bernie is taken into the woods, he begs Tom to spare him, saying "Look into your heart", Tom fires the gun to fake the murder, he tells Bernie to run and hide. Caspar assumes Leo's position as boss of the city, controlling the police and using them to destroy Leo's operations, meanwhile Tom begins settling disagreements between Caspar and his trusted but brutal and homosexual enforcer Eddie "the Dane" Dane (J.E. Freeman). Dane confirms that Tom's men did not see him murder Bernie, he is taken to Miller's Crossing to find Bernie's body, Tom nearly cracks as they near the location, but they find a body that has been shot in the face and birds have disfigured him. Tom finds out that Bernie returned, killed Dane's lover Mink (Steve Buscemi), also his lover, and placed his body in the woods, Bernie tries to blackmail Tom into killing Caspar. Eddie Dane denies betraying Caspar, after Tom uses Mink's unknown whereabouts to convince Caspar, he needs to decide who to trust and who to kill, in rage Caspar beats Dane before shooting him in the head, Tom then arranges a meeting between Caspar and Bernie, Caspar is under the pretext that he will be meeting Mink. Bernie gets the jump on Caspar and kills him, Tom arrives after this and tricks Bernie into handing over his gun, after a discussion of who will be blamed and the retribution for blackmailing Bernie again blames Tom to spare his life, saying "Look into your heart", Tom replies "What heart?" and shoots him. With Caspar and Eddie Dane dead, Leo resumes his position as top boss, Verna has her way back Leo's trust, but reacts coldly towards Tom, on the day Bernie is buried Leo announces he and Verna are engaged, he also offers Tom his job back, Tom refuses and stands back watching Leo depart, the future is questionable. Also starring Mike Starr as Frankie, Al Mancini as Tic-Tac, Richard Woods as Mayor Dale Levander, Thomas Toner as O'Doole, Home Alone 3's Olek Krupa as Tad, Michael Jeter as Adolph, Sam Raimi as Snickering Gunman and Frances McDormand as Mayor's Secretary. Byrne is brilliant as the cool, calculating man behind the throne of the boss, Finney is impressive, Harden gives a great Bette Davis style performance as the woman two men are in love with, and supporting actors like Polito and Turturro give terrific performances as well. I will be completely honest and say that I had to really concentrate to understand everything going on, but even if I didn't it had plenty of moments to remember, including the gory assassination attempt with guns blazing, there are some perfectly over-the-top violent sequences, it is a well written, well acted and has all the right ingredients to keep you fixed, a satisfactory neo-noir black comedy crime drama. Very good!

Reeking of the Coen brothers noir, "Miller's Crossing" offers a great cast, big bucks, glowing reviews, and superlatives up the wazoo from the public. So, if you're like most people and especially if you like Coen products, watch it. However, expect a contrived gangster flick of the Edward G. or Cagney ilk, devoid of anything with which to empathize. A classy but obvious fabrication with staginess and no one to care about, "Miller's Crossing" plays out like so much gangster era pulp fiction with the players dutifully going through the requisite motions in fine style. Recommendable but not memorable. (B)

reviews.review_title: An excellent outing from the Coen Brothers
reviews.content: This was a great film, with several flashes of the brilliance that appears so often in the Coen Brothers movies over the past 20 years. The entire cast was great, especially a baby-faced Gabriel Byrne (so young!) and a spastic John Tuturo, and it was fun to see Frances McDormand sassing her way through a few scenes as the mayor's secretary. Altogether a great entry in their canon, and definitely one to see if you've not watched it, especially if you're a fan of of their later movies. (If you want a Coen Brothers quick fix, you should definitely watch "Ballad of Buster Scruggs" on Netflix; it's really good.)

reviews.review_title: Funny ah ah but not dramatic
reviews.content: A strange little film. Once again the Coen Brothers want to make an anti-genre film. This time they attack the genre of the gangster mafia in an eastern city that does not need a name but has to be big during prohibition. That mafia is working in clubs with bars and gambling tables, and in racketeering for protection. Two rival gangs and one chap taken in between Irish and Italian bosses or would-like-to-be-sole bosses. He has an affair with the girl friend of the Irish man and he shifts to the other side but then he is demanded to execute the brother of the woman, which he fakes and then this brother turns against him and he finally manages, after many sessions of punching and upper cutting that leave him every time healthy and strong, to trick and trap the brother who belongs to the Irish gang and the Italian boss into confronting each other at his own place and the brother kills the Italian boss and our man kills the brother and disguises the two deaths in a mutual gun fight and killing. He is back with his first boss the surviving Irish man who is going to marry the woman of before and forgives our man. But this one refuses that forgiveness that he has not asked and walks away. We will note a slight touch of Jewishness on that Irish man for the funeral of the brother. The cops in that prohibition situation are providing the street entertainment and the cleaning sessions in some clubs that are so wide open that a whole brigade of cops could run in without breaking the slightest piece of glass. But the best part remains the machine gun fights between the Irish boss and the hit men sent to assassinate him by the competitor. The chandelier turns into a "windmill" that is in fact a "bullet mill" and it is funny though it lasts only a second. Overkill is the motto and so many bullets and noise for just nothing is like using the space shuttle to go buy your daily bread at the next block bakery.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU, University Paris 1 Pantheon Sorbonne, University Paris 12 Créteil, CEGID

A truly original, under-rated and undiscovered "Neo-Noir/Gangster Movie", with a very intellectual and unpredictable scrip, with dark humor + irony outlining the incredible dialog. Stylized and much atmospheric photography and direction. Music that gets under your skin and performances that stay with you forever.The film makers could have been influenced by "A Fistful of Dollars" (1964) but they have made a one-of-a-kind film with Miller's Crossing. Its a story about a gambler with dark motives, who is taking advantage of the conflict going on between two rival gangster groups. He moves among the two groups, with a moral code all of his own, while carrying out a highly intellectual and dark Machiavellian plan.The script is excellent and along with the brilliant acting, all moving through a very atmospheric underworld, exploring themes like friendship, betrayal, once put together they all make a small masterpiece. Perhaps (in my opinion) the Coen's best film. Gabriel Byrne is FLAWLESS as "Tom Reagan". He creates the type of character that stays with you forever, and he does it with simplicity. Probably among one of the most complex characters ever written. Full of dualities (as most Noir characters should be) and of course "damned" and self destructive (by choice).To sum up, this is definitely one of those films someone has to see a second time (as with most brilliant films). It's a guarantee you will see new things each time you watch it.Excellent!

Famously pulling from other gangster films, film noir, and Dashiell Hammett novels, the Coens cook up a coldly volatile tale following Gabriel Byrne, a samurai-like Irish mobster who is right hand to stubborn crime boss Albert Finney, who dismisses Byrne's advice to accommodate the ambitious Italian, hilariously animated Jon Polito, and when caught in a gang war Byrne finds that he's more at home looking out for his own interests. Albert Finney was born to play a mob boss. That's just the way he's wired. He has the look and the personality that can take on a character like that. I've never been a very big fan of Gabriel Byrne and can't make myself like his presence, however he never ruins a movie for me, for he was in The Usual Suspects, and here in Miller's Crossing, there's no denying he is good. Miller's Crossing is the sort of film that you cannot stop once you start, because it creates an entire world and seclusively involves all of the actors, camera, dialogue, and tone.The dialogue, for instance, takes you on a long, fun, rhythmic ride, partially mimicking noirs like Double Indemnity or The Big Sleep and detective novels, but really using the familiar earthy style as a springboard to transcend it with its own lightning-quick, exhaustingly sharp semantic understanding throughout the film's created universe. It's just a riveting entertainment, boosted by very small clever touches in the story that turn into powerful blots.The movie's biggest highlight is the uproarious Jon Polito as the Italian boss whose temper and animation are those of cartoon characters that Bugs Bunny would outsmart much to our enjoyment.The score unfortunately guts the atmosphere that is promised by a magnificently stylish scene early on when Finney confronts hit men in a Tommy gun fight in and outside of his house while his Megaphone plays Ol' Danny Boy. But that's not to say it severs you from the movie's tractor beam, which is quite a strong one.

Miller's Crossing may be the most underrated film of all time. The Cohen Brothers' writing is brilliant. The use of explorative/revealing cinematography is creative & supports the story. Plus it has the best performances ever by Jon Polito, Gabriel Byrne & John Turturro. 10!

This is the best gangster film since Godfather II and one of the most fascinating films I've ever seen. It is populated by tough people (or those trying to be) who are trying to make it in an unforgiving, brutal world. It is clear to me a couple of the characters have absolutely no feeling. You can't tell me that the rest don't though. It is really restrained but it is just under the surface. Look at Byrne's pained expressions whenever Verna is around or even spoken of. Leo seems to really care for Tom. Frankie and TicTac even have soft sides. Caspar clearly does but since he's "runnin things" he can't show it much. No one can. The fine cast brings this story to life and the direction and cinematography are second to none. This is one of the few films that seem to get better with repeated viewings.

reviews.review_title: First Ever Gangster Movie for Feminists
reviews.content: The film is near over - a fat man with high blood pressure is hollering from out of an arm-chair. Gabriel Byrne is on the floor, it must be his 10th time to have been knocked onto the ground - from all sorts of characters -henchmen, his female lover, his male lover, his boss and so on - Anyways, thankfully the hollering guy has stopped screaming now, and instead of watching the films end - I thought I would log on and say that I looked forward to this film having read all the positive reviews - but no, this is not a gangster movie - I really have no idea what the hell Joel & Ethan created here. From reading the other reviews on here I guess i missed out clues, clues such as the sound of the creaking corridor floor board 36 minutes 25 seconds into the film.

Widely regarded as the Coens' best film alongside Fargo, Miller's Crossing is a quite singular take on the gangster genre, worth contrasting to the more "classic" Goodfellas: ostensibly an homage to Dashiell Hammett, it is in fact a pure Coen brothers' movie (though not as pure as Fargo), replete as it is with their trademark sharp writing, cold but gorgeous visuals and superb performances.The incredibly complex screenplay revolves around a Jewish bookie, Bernie Bernbaum (John Turturro, in his first Coen film). Apparently, he has angered an Italian boss, Johnny Caspar (Jon Polito), a volatile fella who wants him dead, plain and simple. However, Irish leader Leo O' Bannion (Albert Finney) disagrees, mainly because Bernie's sister Verna (Marcia Gay Harden) is his mistress. And in between these two stands Tom Reagan (Gabriel Byrne), a taciturn, calculating hit-man who has an agenda of his own, derived from a bizarre moral code and a tendency to favor rationality over violence. The full extent of his involvement is too complicated to explain - the fact that he's sleeping with Verna and has huge gambling debts is just the tip of the iceberg.The Coens' detractors often accuse them of creating beautifully framed yet hollow pictures, their characters being ice-cold constructions instead of human beings. Miller's Crossing proves, perhaps better than any other film, that statement's lack of veracity: it's the characters and their interactions that carry the narrative. In fact, more often than not they're what keeps the viewer alert in spite of the labyrinthine plot. Exactly who is double-crossing who and why might not seem clear at first, but seeing those people talk and act in a universe that gets more violent by the minute gives the film that special something that separates it from lesser crime movies.Byrne, being the one who has to guide us through the entire feature, is cold and seemingly merciless, but beneath the icy facade lies a warmth that makes his performance all the more effective. Finney plays to similar strengths, giving the impression of his godfather being an old fool and then showing he is actually the most dangerous person around. Polito, Harden and J.E. Freeman (Eddie Dane) are asked to play their roles (edgy boss, femme fatale and psychotic henchman respectively) by the book and do so while still adding that peculiar Coen ingredient, and Steve Buscemi's one-scene appearance provides some fun amongst the mayhem. And then there's Turturro, the man without whom the movie would, in a way, fall flat: his character is the MacGuffin that sets everything in motion, an opportunistic, unreliable scumbag to whom the actor gives life with a subtle, creepy intensity. Perhaps he's the reason the Coens are accused of coldness: the critics saw how chilly Bernie was in his actions and found it apt to brand everyone involved with the same adjective. How wrong were they: Miller's Crossing is a piece of cinema that will mesmerize, move and terrify in equal measure, a gangster picture that diverts from conventions by sticking to them. A masterwork.

I raise my hate for this movie if i wear any,if anyone ask me what is one of the best Coen movies?i say Miller crossing is one of themThe intro its homage to God father I opening scene,the cinematography is great,the story even better.It tells Tom ragan is a mob right hand man,caught between mob war and have to choose a right side to ensure his savety.Gabriel bryne is great in here as Tom ragan he capture a calmness of an expert mob who knows what hes doing.Theres slightly pleasent cameo of Frances mcdormand and director Sam raimi.
If u want to fall in love with Coen movies definetely this one is a start.

reviews.review_title: Very original for a movie taking from every other movie of the genre.
reviews.content: A mobster movie has to be different to get attention. It has to show some aspect that other movie's don't, or else it's just your average mob movie. "Miller's Crossing" takes from all the mobster and gangster films, along with other movies, but at the same time it's so original. The cinematography is beautiful, and the characters are uniquely molded, as is the plot. This is one of the Coen's best films, and one of the better mobster movies ever released.Two gangs are fighting, and Tom Reagan (Gabriel Byrne) is right in the middle. He first works for Leo (Albert Finney) and his Irish mob, but after sleeping with his lady Verna (Marcia Gay Harden) he is kicked out. He then goes to Johnny Caspar (John Polito), the Italian crime boss. Tom's first order of business is to kill bookie, Bernie (John Turturro). Bernie is the brother of Verna, who Tom has fallen for. In the end, what we have is a tale of finding compassion, and having morals (no matter how backwards they are).The highlight of every Coen brothers film is the lovely camera work. They always have good acting, an original and darkly funny story, but on top of everything, the camera work always stands out. Each shot is set up as perfectly as it could be and this is a great looking film.Gabriel Byrne is a very good lead, and my only gripe is sometimes I couldn't decipher what he was saying beneath that thick Irish accent. The accent was necessary for the character, so it's not even really a gripe. Albert Finney didn't have a whole lot of screen time, but he grabbed all he could from what he does have. Whoever knew a scene with Finney shooting a nobody with a tommy gun could be so dramatic. John Polito is menacing. John Turturro is excellent as a coward posing as a slick tough guy. Marcia Gay Harden gives a wonderfully reserved performance. Wonderful performances all around.This is the Coen brother's first film to be both humorous and dramatic. The drama is plentiful as is the suspense, even with characters who weren't created to be cared about. When Tom stands in the forest deciding whether or not to shoot Bernie, my heart was racing, and I could have cared less about Bernie. The cops who give into the mob's every whim and tip their hats to Tom are humorous. This is more action and drama, but there is still a perfect amount of humor thrown in.Overall, this is an excellent mob movie, with inspired performances, an original plot, nice looking cinematography and typical Coen brilliance found everywhere.My rating: *** 1/2 out of ****. 115 mins. R for violence.

When the Coen brothers make a movie I am almost sure I will not be disappointed. Even in the movies not as good as 'Blood Simple' and 'Fargo' there is enough to enjoy. I had that with 'Raising Arizona', 'Barton Fink' and 'The Hudsucker Proxy' and I really had that with 'The Big Lebowski', 'O Brother, Where Art Thou', 'The Man Who Wasn't There' and now finally 'Miller's Crossing'. This movie is a gangster movie although it never really feels that way. I have that feeling with most of the Coen movies and in a way I like it.The movie is good. The story is pretty clever and everyone does what's expected from him. The little things make this movie a little better than just good. The opening shot is one of them. The dialogue is another, although sometimes it feels a little too clever for real people. I also had that with 'Pulp Fiction'. There it worked really well, here it works really well for most of the time. As you expect from the Coens everything looks great. I mentioned the opening shot but there are more. In one scene a whole police force is shooting at a club because there is someone in that club shooting at them. It looks beautiful. And I must not forget the performances. Gabriel Byrne as Tom, Marcia Gay Harden as Verna and Steve Buscemi as Mink are good, Jon Polito as Johnny Caspar, Albert Finney as Leo and John Turturro as Bernie are even better. I think the greatest performance was from J.E. Freeman as Eddie Dane. All this together make 'Miller's Crossing' a very good movie and if you like movies from the Coen brothers, crime movies or actually just movies in general you have to see this.

Gabriel Byrne plays Irish gangster Tom Reagan, right hand man to crime boss Leo (Albert Finney). When trouble stirs between Jewish and Italian mobsters, Reagan uses his position of trust to manipulate those around him.I love gangster movies and Miller's Crossing, by the Coen Brothers, delivers much of what I find so entrancing about the genre: strong characters, wonderful period detail, explosive violence and a cool film noir/neo noir style. But for some reason—and I haven't quite put my finger on it yet—the film didn't grip me as much as I had expected, certainly not in the way that The Godfather or Once Upon A TIme in America did.It might be that I didn't quite swallow how effortlessly Reagan exploited every situation when, in reality, he would have been rumbled and 'taken care of'. It could be that the performances were a little too cartoonish for my liking, the gangsters almost a parody of those seen in other films. Or it could be that, underneath all of the great cinematography and stylish touches, there really isn't that much of a story to be told.6 out of 10. Worth seeing for Albert Finney toting a tommy gun and for Sam Raimi being riddled with machine gun fire.

reviews.review_title: A brilliantly constructed update of old gangster movies
reviews.content: It is rare indeed that a tired, cliche-ridden film genre - in this case the '30s gangster movie - is not only resurrected, but markedly improved upon. The sharp and witty exchanges between the panoply of colourful protagonists are the least you would expect, particularly in a Coen brothers movie. But to couple this with such immense depth and complexity of plot and character is astounding. Add to this Barry Sonnenfeld's dazzling cinematography, a memorable soundtrack, and the Coen's penchant for constructing one magical movie moment after another, and you have as close to perfection as film-making gets.

Where do i start...great job all around.casted great,cool script,mobbish w/out being a mob movie.the clothes,the guns,the cars,& especially the vocabulary!! 'ya get me,see?!? Cross Leo again,& i'll do plenty.....tell Lazar i won't take it personal...jesus tom...he already know that.

reviews.review_title: The best organized crime film of all time
reviews.content: The Coen brothers are at the peak of their powers in this magnificent organized crime film. This movie has got it all: a complex plot that keeps you on the edge of your seat, interesting and well developed characters, and as per usual with the Coen brothers, great dialog. Virtually every line in this movie is dripping with hilarious black humor quotes. But have no fear, that doesn't take away from the seriousness of the movie, it just adds an extra layer of depth.Due to the fact that this movie is so complex and well written it stands up to repeat viewings as well as The Big Lebowski, a later Coens' masterwork. You'll catch things on repeat viewings that you didn't catch the first time that adds to the enjoyment of the film. This is the best organized crime film of all time.

reviews.review_title: Utter Brilliance, truly an amazing film.
reviews.content: To this day, it still amazes me how much this film went by the wayside in 1990. Granted, Goodfellas was a masterpiece, but I find Miller's Crossing to be beyond brilliant. The Coens accomplished something in this film that Scorsese could never begin to imagine. While being an underrated classic, Miller's Crossing is a triumphant tale of expecting the unexpected. As the tag line states, "Up is down, black is white, and nothing is what it seems". Gabriel Byrne's performance of Tom Reagan is flawless, genuine, and unforgettable. Jon Polito, John Tuturro, Albert Finney, J.E. Freeman and Marcia Gay Harden also deserve the same recognition for their stunning performances. No other film, in the history of cinema, has ever felt so magical and alive. From beginning to end, MC is filled with twists and turns that make you feel like you hope the movie will never end.The scenes themselves are like something out of a Picasso painting. Rather than rambling on, I'll name a few of my favorites: -the opening scene with Caspar, Tom, and Leo -the unforgettable "Danny Boy" scene with Leo -"Bernie's walk" into the depths of Miller's Crossing -Tom opening up to Leo about he and VernaI could go on forever. Every scene is instantly classic, with a touch of gold from the Coens.In addition to the beautiful cinematography, the dialogue is sheer genius. While I enjoy every single line in the film, I particularly loved what Tom, Leo, and Caspar had to say. If there was ever I movie that I could nearly quote from beginning to end, it would most certainly be Miller's Crossing.What else could possibly add to a flawless movie? Carter Burwell's score. While Burwell is known for his excellent scores in Fargo and Barton Fink, he truly achieved greatness with the Miller's Crossing score.The thing to walk away from with a film like Miller's Crossing can easily be summed up by the film's tag line: "Up is down, black is white, and nothing is what it seems". Not only does this concept apply to the plot of the film, but it applies to the viewer's expectations. Most people who walked into the theater in 1990 were expecting a typical gangster film, like The Godfather or Once Upon A Time In America. What they got was the exact opposite. Rather than seeing one-sided mobsters carry out the wishes of their boss, we see a rebellious Tom Reagan who has had enough with Leo's stubborn and egotistical judgments. With that in mind, the viewer sees an organized crime boss turned on his heels and thrown to the whim of an ex-underling.

reviews.review_title: One of the most powerful uses of dialogue in modern film!
reviews.content: A rare gem of film that has remained relatively unacknowledged (when compared to more commercially successful Coen brothers films), Miller's Crossing stands alongside The Big Lebowski as the Coen's best film to date and indeed as one of the finest examples of it's genre whether that be the Gangster or Noir genre. This is a film that boasts perfection from all quarters from the acting, the casting, the writing, the directing, the cinematography, to the scoring.Of course, its standout strength is the dialogue which is not only the best example of Coen dialogue but perhaps the most powerful use of dialogue in modern film. The main thrust of the film's quick and steady pace comes from the lyrical and relentless back and forth between the film's characters (and in typical Noir fashion, this is usually between Tom and someone else).As is the case in most films, the level of the writing raises the level of the acting. Each of the actors' performances are first rate and indeed there are many career bests given here. When I lament the fact that the likes of Pachino and De Niro don't consistently produce the quality they did in the 70's and early 80's, I remind myself that we just don't have the quality of writing as we did then and while films have become better in other respects they've never quite reached the same heights from the point of view of the writing. Joel and Ethan Coen are amongst a relatively small number of contemporary writers who are consistently working on that level and Miller's Crossing is the perfect example of great actors being fueled by great writing. Finney and Polita clearly revel in the expounding of their luscious lines while J.E. Freeman simply burns a whole in the screen. Of course, this is Byrne's film from start to finish and he carries it well with a distinct and unique brand of cool as he delivers immortal line after immortal line with pure gusto.Those who claim the violence in this film is gratuitous need to re-watch. For example, in the most violent scene involving Casper and the Dane, the violence is used to illustrate the complex aspects to Casper's character (e.g., his paternal attitude towards his 'boys' and his sociopathic attitude towards killing; his adherence to ethics and his vengeance against those who betray theirs). On top of that, speaking from a technical point of view, violence in Coen films is typically choreographed into the action scenes in a relatively artistic manner where it is used as a counterpoint or visual exclamation mark to augment and punctuate the action and/or tension of a scene. Nowhere is this more true than in Miller's Crossing a film that boasts some of the Coens most memorable and best choreographed action scenes.As for the symbolism of the hat and the dream sequence where Tom must chase his, I heard before that the Coens claim there was none. This is difficult to believe as the film is very much about thinking oneself out of problems and not loosing one's head and Tom himself explicitly equates thinking to hats during the film. But that's the great thing about symbolism in clever films - there's a lot one can make of even a hat.

Far too wordy throughout, which makes it hard to tell what (if any) dramatic reason there is for any of the events in the film to happen.Lots of people get beaten or shot but nobody seems to gain anything from it.Clearly a tribute to the gangster movies if an earlier age, it is well filmed, but John Turturro is the only cast member to give a performance of any interest.

This is the Coens' take on gangster flicks, and it's mesmerizing. Memorable characters, magnificent acting, and most importantly, an incredible plot make this movie a must see for movie fans.  Along with "the Usual Suspects", this is Byrne's best movie.  Also, who knew Albert Finney could act this tough?

reviews.review_title: Look in your heart! Look in your heart!
reviews.content: The Coen brothers hit the jackpot again with this film. They are masters of crime flicks with a twist or two. You never know what is going to happen and the surprises just make you stay there til the end.Gabriel Byrne (The Usual Suspects) appears to be playing both sides against the middle to keep a gang war from breaking out. He's also sleeping with his boss' girlfriend, and part of his job is to kill her brother. Just the place I want to be.The girlfriend is Marcia Gay Harden (Pollack, Mystic River, American Gun) and she turns in a super performance as one who, in the words of her brother (John Turturro), will "...sleep with anyone..." With Albert Finney, Steve Buscemi, and Michael Jeter, this is a sure bet.

Tom:  "I don't hate anyone."Verna:  "Or like anyone."Tom Reagan is a smart guy.  Easily the smartest gangster in the circles he travels in.  He sees all the angles and knows all the right plays to make. But he is a terrible gambler, as his outstanding debts to Lazarre will attest.  Why is that?  Simple:  this is a man who wants to lose.  He has brains, but no heart, he knows it, and he can't stand it.  How else to explain the actions of a man who could easily run the whole town yet who manages to screw himself out of everything?This, I believe, is what gives Miller's Crossing its resonance for those of us who champion the film to the mostly indifferent masses. The movie itself is a caricature of a gangster film, with a nicely twisting and turning plot, as should be expected from the Coen brothers, but at its center is Tom, tragic in his own mind.  How a viewer reacts to this character will determine his or her feelings about the film.  If you see some (maybe even too much) of yourself in his cynical nature, his orchestration of events which lead to his being repeatedly beaten and having his life threatened, and culminating in the complete loss of his former stature and the woman he almost loved, can be pretty affecting.  On the other hand, the character might understandably leave the viewer cold or even contemptuous of his behavior.  In this case, someone might admire some aspects of the film but feel the movie is without a heart, and this person would not be wrong.Regardless of how one feels about Tom's apparent masochism, the film has some undeniably wonderful scenes (which I won't spoil here), first-rate acting all around, and another beautiful score by Carter Burwell, who has yet to disappoint me.  And despite the impression someone might get from my analysis of Tom Reagan, this is a movie with sometimes hilarious rapid-fire dialogue, especially whenever Tom is dealing with people he doesn't like. Which is nearly every scene he is in.  Like Rick Blaine in Casablanca, Tom Reagan is a master of projecting his cynicism onto others with effortless sarcasm.And also like Rick Blaine, he always does it without a smile.

reviews.review_title: A top-notch gangster film from the Coen brothers
reviews.content: "Miller's Crossing" is a prohibition-era gangster film from the Coen brothers. In it, a mob war erupts when an Irish crime boss foolishly takes a stand to protect his lover's brother. It soon becomes apparent that just about everybody has an angle to play and it's up to the one man who sees all of the angles to try to keep the peace.The cast is excellent. In my mind the standout performance comes from Coen brothers mainstay Jon Polito, who plays an Italian crime boss who's sick of getting 'the high hat'. There's also quality work here from Gabriel Byrne, Albert Finney, Marcia Gay Harden, John Turturro & J.E. Freeman.The direction is well-handled, as you might expect from the Coen brothers, and the film also features a memorable score from Carter Burwell. The script, co-authored by the Coen brothers, is filled to the brim with snappy dialogue and has no trouble navigating the many twists in the tale without losing the viewer along the way.Given the film's polish, along with the fine script and top-drawer acting, I'm very surprised that it went entirely unnoticed during awards season. Luckily, the reputation that the Coen brothers have built since then has ensured that this worthwhile film will have a devoted audience for years to come.

At the start of the film, Tom Regan - played to perfection by Gabriel Byrne - stands dutifully behind the swivel chair of Leo O'Brannon (Albert Finney). At the end, Leo walks away from Tom, at Miller's Crossing ...And that is the summum bonum of the entire film ... the slow turning of the tables. The entire experience remains unforgettable even for the unpredictability and ambivalence Byrne brings to his portrayal of Tom Regan, imbuing the character with an underlying menace which pervades his portrayal throughout, so that his query, towards the memorable close of the film, "What heart?" assumes a significance all its own. Though John Turturro's turn as the homosexual Bernie Bernbaum is often touted as the star performance in the film, I myself was not so enthralled by it; the character appears to me to be a bit sketchily drawn, with some gaps remaining to be filled in. And Turturro, in my view, pitches his act just a wee bit overboard, so that it does not remain entirely credible.No ... The film, in my view, belongs to Byrne and Byrne alone. Further, it is also memorable because it essentially abandons the usual bullets-and-bloodshed formula which most gangster epics adopt, and concentrates on the psychological aspect of the whole thing ... it's a fascinating exercise in mindplay and, perhaps for that very reason, is intellectually draining as well.What was going on in Tom's mind at the end of it all? I've yet to figure out the answer ... and that's where 'Miller's Crossing' scores.

reviews.review_title: Among the Greatest American Films Ever Made
reviews.content: Sadly, Miller's Crossing is not universally recognized as such, and to this day remains more of a cult classic. The dialog is razor sharp, fast paced and witty, steeped in quirky language from a bygone era. The acting is stellar, the photography poetic, and the score has a haunting melancholy about it. The sets perfectly portray a prohibition-era city. They create a world you want to jump into and inhabit for a while, even though it's a world full of deceit, treachery, mayhem and murder. The complex plot may require an additional viewing or more to capture all the nuances that make up a terrific story, that at it's core, is less gangster movie and more of an existential meditation. I can think of no other movie with writing as good as this. Simply masterful, it is laced with dark humor and acerbic wit, and once you put all the pieces of the puzzle together, you realize what a tremendous achievement the film really is. The litany of quotable lines is endless. Some of the action scenes are legendary, the actors are all well cast and developed, and do a superb job. My only complaint about this great film is that it had to end.

reviews.review_title: Slick and stylish, one of the best films the Coen brothers ever made
reviews.content: This is truly a unique film. Pretty much everything works. It is one of those films where not a single character is wasted. All of them played to pitch perfection. Those worthy of praise are Gabriel Byrne in the lead role (as cool as you will ever see him), Steve Buscemi who delivers an amazing performance in a 5-minute roles, and John Turturro who is brilliant as usual. The story is a unique one, multiple viewings are thoroughly recommended. Dialogue's sharp, cinematography's great, and that's pretty much everything you need to know. Now go see it right away.A slick and stylish gangster film, this is one of the best films the Coen brothers ever made, perhaps better than Goodfellas - Moose finds this film worthy of a 10.

Boring, boring, boring
The actors repeating their texts without passion. Where is the story? Unreal!
Don't want to see it again.

reviews.review_title: The piece is a fabulous testament to taut and grown up crime film writing/making.
reviews.content: Miller's Crossing is the superb gangster drama not necessarily covering the exploits of a man who is a gangster. Certainly, the lead is surrounded by organised crime and folk more apt to the gangster or criminal way of life, but he is more shrewd; he's the weakest, and certainly one of the more soft bodied characters in the piece, but almost certainly one of the more intelligent. If most crime dramas, of this ilk or otherwise, appear to revolve around tough guys doing what they do and throwing their weight around in getting what they want, using their minds only when they're required to get the upper hand in an aggressive conflict, Miller's Crossing is about a guy whom trembles at the thought of having to kill someone, but is instead able-bodied enough to balance several relations with some rather unremitting people. We enjoy the film that is born out of this notion, the film driven by a man getting on with things via his mouth and his mind, not his aggression; items which bring about great dialogue and twisting, turning narratives we are asked to keep up with rather than wall to wall stunts.Gabriel Byrne plays Tom Reagan, a likable Irish-American rouge in amidst the filthy upper echelons of a crime syndicate in an unspecified American city during the time of prohibition. He stands, in his bosses office, as the Coen's open their film in a fashion akin to that of The Godfather: a long take of a man speaking in a gangster's office relaying a 'pitch' to a rival gangster; a man outlining this-and-that to someone whilst going on at length about an issue which means a great deal to him. We cover a chapter in the life of a middleman, a middleman intermingling with several parties more broadly representing the amoral American dream; a guy hopping around from camp to camp and ultimately getting himself up to his neck in trouble as a result of his actions. When the time comes for Tom's boss to speak, the film has both men clash over what it is that either party desire, establishing conflict but either of their respectively stubborn natures so as not to be threatened in what is a threatening environment. The individual whom speaks first, the Italian-American Johnny Caspar (Polito), wants a man dead; Tom's boss, Leo (Finney), a power-mad gangster with delusions that he is invincible, doesn't, and the film constructs Tom's own manoeuvring around the screen in a fashion that has him blend into both mob bosses compositions – thus, alluding to a greater extent of cross pollination which will come about later on.There is a theory more broadly linked to that of writings on the genre of film noir that classical leads of said genre struggle to come to terms with their environment when they are let loose from the locale of the urban, crime drenched city and placed into a countryside. Historically, leads of film's such as Miller's Crossing have flagged in rural-inclined places of trees and fields and farms, or whatnot; the film's unnerving cut, to what looks like the perspective of someone looking directly upwards at the sky during a process of being carried on something, greets us after this office-set opening – is it a person's literal perspective? Is that person perhaps dead? The locale will come to play a greater part in the film later on, the name of this place being the titular Miller's Crossing; a zone on the outskirts of the city in which those therein are permitted to extend their travels in another direction; a fork to other place, if you will - a later scene of great intensity acting as the stepping stone to a bleaker, more cold blooded existence for our lead Tom away from the path to that of what he's presently on.The narrative is what it is, a water-tight labyrinth that takes care of itself; we enjoy our lead's company and aligned ourselves with him enough to become greatly enthused in his ventures that come to feature an array of other lowlifes as a mob war comes to break out around him. Other prominent players in Tom's life lie in the form of the girlfriend to Leo in Verna (Gay Harden), as well as John Turturro's feral gambler Bernie Bernbaum; Verna wears very little when we first see her interact with Tom, and the tone of their conversation encapsulates the nature of the world they occupy: blunt and dry in spite of the fact they're quite close. We identify that he's there to collect his hat at her place, which he left having been too intoxicated to remember to take it, and there is this prominent sense of Tom walking a fine line in his life when it becomes obvious he's seeing Verna behind his bosses' back; a man, in Leo, to whom he is so close that either character appears to just be able to visit the other at whatever hour they desire if there is a problem needing fleshing out.Turturro does well with his character, a guy whom we first observe just seemingly 'appear' in Tom's dwelling – sat there in a chair, as his presence catches us all off guard. His attire has him eerily blend into the furniture within which he's perched, while his nature of manoeuvring around as he does and getting the jump on us all alludes to a greater extent of trickery and slipperiness which later becomes apparent when things intensify, and Bernie does not play by the rules laid down to him. The film is an often spellbinding crime drama; a glorious period piece weaving its way down challenging avenues and indulging us in the sort of narrative filmmaking with which we ought to engage.

This film is an example of the Coen brothers at their mercurial best. The central performances by Byrne, Finney and Turturro are brilliant. The character of Bernie accurately represents the Jewish shyster bookie/gangster of the period (no anti-semitism in my comment). There are characteristic touches of Coen humour especially the scenes where people vibrate, when the trigger of the machine gun goes off, after being shot. A great movie one of the best!

I have never been such a big fan of the Coenbrothers but this movie is indeed a gangsterclassic that is deserving his place in the best ten gangstermovies of all time. The Coenbrothers show us in a perfect way that in a world of crimer you better not trust anyone but yourself. Actors like John Turturro who usually work on my nerves were doing some great things here, especially the scene in the woods where Turturro waspleading for his life and a couple of minutes later coming back and being the centre of the movie. That's indeed the strongest thing about "Miller"s crossing" that apart from the machine guns and the costumes it's apart from many other gangstermovies cos a copy from "The godfather" isn't anymore needed.

reviews.review_title: Great script from the Coens in this prohibition drama...
reviews.content: This DVD was lent to me some time ago and I decided it's time to get it returned but I thought I'd better watch it first! I quite like the Coens' work, but this is one that has escaped me thus far, hence the borrowing of said DVD. It's very definitely a Coen brothers script with some excellent dialogue and plenty of plot twists. I'll give you my thoughts later, but here's a brief summary first (summary haters and those that don't wish to know anything about the plot please take that guy out into the woods & deal with him while I write the next paragraph).Tom Reagan is adviser to Leo, the mob boss who runs things around here. Rival boss, Johnny Caspar wants Leo to give him permission to have Bernie Bernbaum killed because he's making problems for his gambling syndicate. Now Bernie's sister, Verna is seeing Leo and so Leo is reluctant to upset the apple cart (if you know what I mean). Also, Verna is seeing Tom on the side and if Leo ever found out about that there was gonna be some big trouble for him. Add to this the fact that, Tom is also a bit of a gambler and has run up quite a debt, but insists on paying it off without any help. So, one day Casper makes Tom an offer and, as you can probably guess, this is where all the fun starts I hope you understand that lot! I'm gonna leave it there so as not to enrage the spoiler police too much.As I said at the beginning, this film has a truly excellent script with some great dialogue and clever plot twists. It's a very well made film with a very appropriate soundtrack (you'll know what I mean if you've seen it). All the main cast put in very good performances; Gabriel Byrne as Tom Regan, Marcia Gay Harden as Verna, John Turturro as Bernie Bernbaum, Jon Polito I particularly liked as Johnny Caspar, Albert Finney as Leo and it was nice to see a cameo for Steve Buscemi as Mink.Although it has a great script, I found it didn't grab my attention the way other Coen brothers films have. Or maybe films have been made since that do what this does, but better. I don't quite know what it is, but this one seems to lack the punch that other Coen brothers films have. I felt that, although he is very good, Gabriel Byrne seems very subdued all the way through and this appears out of character for someone in his position. But aside from that, it's well worth seeing Recommended (if only for Albert Finney wielding a Thompson Machine Gun to great effect).My score: 7.5/10

BEWARE OF SPOILERS BELOW I found this film painfully slow and wondering around pointlessly up to about the first hour. The second hour was more interesting though not brilliant, it began to get somewhat interesting from the time Byrne was asked to shoot Turturo his Jewish girlfriend's brother.The plot was muddled and hard to follow in many of its details while it lacked real depth and tension and many of the major characters came across as very cartoonish and wishy washy, Polito and Finney for example weren't at all convincing as authoritative top mafia bosses in their city though Byrne's character was quite satisfactory.The study of human reactions gave it some depth e.g the refusal of Byrne to shoot Turturo and the latter's behaviour towards the one who spared his life at enormous risk to himself.Overall a very mediocre film that's just about worth watching and while granting that in the subject of films personal tastes can differ enormously and one may find a film as being excellent and another as being totally dull I just can't understand why this film is considered as one of the greatest mafia films ever made. It just doesn't have the attributes of a great film particularly an easy to follow yet deep, coherent and suspenseful plot.

reviews.review_title: Not Only is it the Best Coen Brother's Movie (Along With No Country for Old Men and Fargo), it is One of the Best and Most Underrated Movies Ever Made!
reviews.content: I'm going to speak plainly. This is one of the best movies I've ever seen. I loved every minute of it.
