It is one of the most underrated movies ever made in comparison to how good it really is. It got the respect of the critics but after one week it kind of just disappeared. An injustice to this movie.Plot: This movie has a very strong plot. I takes about two viewings to really appreciate it. The reason being is that it is hard to follow until the very end when everything comes together. I applaud both Joel and Ethan Coen for their writing, with the excellent dialog, and the major twists that always keep you guessing but never knowing until it finally happens. Is Tommy betraying Leo and joining Johnny Caspar or does he have other plans? I didn't know until the very end and I doubt you will either. Top notch story which will keep you glued to the screen to the very end.Acting: I love Albert Finney, as Leo, the boss of the Irish gang and the boss of the city. He's one of my favorite actors. I also love Marcia Gay Harden, as Leo's fiancé, Verna, and John Turturro as Bernie Bernbaum, a bookie who Caspar wants dead but is the brother of Verna. They all did fantastic and gave very believable performances But the performances that really blew me away were from the equally great actors Gabriel Byrne as Tommy, the protagonist, Jon Polito as Johnny Caspar, the Italian boss, and J.E. Freeman as The Dane, the adviser and 2nd in command to Johnny Caspar. Gabriel Byrne gave a performance that like the story always kept you guessing. Combining him and the script is what made this movie. Jon Polito was Johnny Caspar and the Italian boss. J.E. Freeman played the most intelligent guy in the movie along with Tommy. Known only as The Dane he was cold, calculating and ruthless. I also loved the quick scene with Steve Buscemi. Enough Said.Genre/Quality: This is a crime film. But it is unusual in that it deals with the Irish mob. It involves a war between the Irish mob who currently control the town and the Italian mob who want control. One of the great points in this movie is the music. The Coen Bros. have always had great music in their movies, but this may have been the best score I've ever heard in a Coen Bros. movie. The camera work was excellent as was the set and art direction. Mixing these four together made this film a low budget but technical masterpiece. The music always fits the scene and the scene always fits the music.Overall this is probably the most underrated movie I've ever watched. It got praise but not enough. I think that the only recent praise I've seen from a critic was Time Magazine where it was included in their Top 100 Movies of All Time. This is a well deserved position. Forget The Godfather Part 3 for the Best Picture Nomination that year. While a great movie it was not better than Miller's Crossing. Goodfellas deserved Best Picture that year but had it not been made that year, Miller's Crossing would have deserved it. This film is all around spectacular and it's a movie that I can watch over and over and over again and never get tired of it. This film receives my highest praises.10/10

reviews.review_title: An Early Coen Brothers; the story takes an hour to come to the boil.
reviews.content: It's Coen Brothers doing1920's prohibition, so it's stylish, dark, great music, class photography, violent in places, the hero is no angel, the cops are corrupt, the cast is having a ball, great set pieces, and the story is strong. Once the story eventually gets going, that is.Second time I watched this I knew I had to concentrate from the start, and that helped. Tom Reagan (Gabriel Byrne) is a Chicago/Irish consigliere to Albert Finney's town capo di tutti capi. Verna (Marcia Gay Harden) is the love interest of both of them, and really, hers is the only sympathetic character, though very thinly written. Gabriel Byrne plays Irish-super-cool-dishy for all it's worth, but the character is neither hero nor antihero, which may be the intention, and it doesn't really work. The ending kind of fits, though.Anyway (SPOILER) Tom switches allegiance (or does he?) to preserve whatever he's got going with Verna, but it takes a full hour to establish all the dynamics. If you concentrate up to then, the whole tension of the story becomes apparent, but they certainly made heavy going of it. I mean, I've now watched it twice and I'm still not certain how Steve Buscemi ended up where he did, and why it mattered.Slow, confusing build up to a worthwhile ending, but thin characters.

reviews.review_title: Not that much of a Rumpus
reviews.content: Miller's Crossing is not your typical gangster film. Its gangsters, Coen Brothers style. Gangsters film noir (not that uncommon you might think, but there haven't been many gangster films in recent years you could classify as noir; while Goodfellas was an amazing film, would you class it as noir?). The gangsters have principles and ethics. And its taken for a given that all the cops are bent. The police chief simply works for the top dog  the man who really runs the town.Leo (Albert Finney) plays the aforementioned top dog, and is an honourable man who keeps his promises. He is constantly supported by loyal lieutenant Tom (Gabriel Byrne), and the two have an almost father-son relationship. When rising mob boss Johnny Caspar (Jon Polito) comes to see him telling him he is going to kill someone under Leo's protection, instead of giving up his charge in order to keep the peace, Leo refuses to allow the hit. What follows is a slow descent into gangland war, with Tom caught right in the middle, trying to prevent all-out war (and Leo finding out about his relationship with Leo's girlfriend, played by Marcia Gay Harden).Tom (Byrne) is an original anti-hero. Caught in the middle of a brewing turf war between rival gangsters, wanting to keep the peace and stay out of it. Unlike most gangsters, he operates with his brain rather than his muscles. Byrne plays it superbly (as we have come to expect from him), with just the right amount of melancholy and self-destructive nature mixed in with honour to ensure he doesn't appear to heroic. In fact, Byrne is the undoubted star of the piece, playing it understated while everyone else finds license to cut loose and overact. Albert Finney, while underused, is terrific, and utilises a wonderful gangster accent  with, rather originally, hint of John Wayne in it, whilst Polito and the rest all have the stereotypical indistinct gravelly voices.What makes the film so atypical of gangster films is its contradicting nature. For instance, early in the film there is a ferocious shootout at Leo's house, but it is played out to the strains of 'Danny Boy', and almost in slow motion. It never appears to be over-dramatic, while the shootouts again hark back to 30s gangster films  lots of tommy guns, with lots of loud bangs, flashes and smoke but very little claret. Further, the Coen Brothers, in keeping with their unconventional tone, utilise a sense of old style filming, with fade outs between scenes  reminiscent of Dad's Army and Golden Age Hollywood films such as Gone With The Wind. The violence is also reasonably restrained for the most part (at least until the end anyway), again in fitting in with the old-style filming.The relationship between Finney & Byrne's characters is also refreshing; they are close confidantes, trusted friends  something not often seen in gangster films. Leo is also a gangster with ethics and principles, and keeps promises to protect people; again not a common gangster trait.But for all it's praiseworthy points, the story itself is a bit of a slow-burner; when compared to classic gangster films like The Godfather and Goodfellas, or even modern ones such as Road to Perdition, the story produces little adrenaline or excitement, and it is hard to become too wrapped up in the story and the plight of the characters.The Coen Brothers seem simply unable to produce a standard generic picture; everything they make always appears to be slightly off-kilter, and Miller's Crossing is no different. So if you want a gangster film that isn't in the 'badda bing badda bang' tradition of Goodfellas, then Miller's Crossing is perfect. But just don't expect a white-knuckle ride.

reviews.review_title: the delicate thread of a hat.
reviews.content: Even gangsters can suffer from a touch of humanity now and again.In between crazed camera moves and wild performances are moments of surprisingly quiet beauty and odd transcience (signified by the softly blowing hat floating its way through the woods). Gabriel Byrne makes for a terrific strong-but-silent man in conflict. John Turturro's shoe-licking coward is equally affecting.I've never seen another film as well-served by visual hyperbole. The control the Coen brothers exhibit in the direction of this film is amazing. Not everyone can move easily between the hyper-active and the quiet. The balance that's struck in this film between showy visual trickery and poetic resonance is really rare.

This movie has one of the best screenplays and cinematography compositions in motion picture history. The frames of this film are perfectly composed and lit like art paintings that, in addition to compelling acting are put in logical progression and tell the story almost without the need for words. It is very rare to see such artistically well done movies. Of course it is also pretty funny watching gangsters lamenting about a code of ethics that constitutes the violation of ethical behavior. Other great examples good movies in the same vane with completely different stories are the silent films of Fritz Lang (Siegfried and Metropolis); or more recent examples: Executive Suite (1954), and Doctor No. (1962).

One of my all time favourites and easily the Coen's best film, Miller's Crossing opened the New York Film Festival in 1990 to strong reviews. The movie benefits from a dark and powerful performance by Gabriel Byrne in a film of like substance that tells an unusual tale of the life of a manipulative, clever gangster. Supporting cast are strong, including Marcia Gay Harden, Albert Finney, John Turturro and Jon Polito.The plot from brother Joel and Ethan Coen is fantastically worked and, after a slow start, really hooks you in as it is put to full use by director Joel. We need more powerful cinema like this; it truly blew me away.Saturday, February 23, 1991 - Forest Hill Chase"Millers Crossing" is still as entertaining second time around. The Coen brothers have produced a film rich in funny, sharp dialogue and with a plot so well worked that one can certainly get full value more than once. At the risk of repeating myself, the performances from Gabriel Byrne, Marcia Gay Harden, Jon Polito and John Turturro are fabulous! Brilliantly directed by Joel Coen, who shows great control!Tuesday, September 17, 1991 - Video

In the echelon of gangster movies--regardless of the era--this ranks in the lower echelon. I couldn't care less about the characters or the plot. The Dick-Tracy-light characters were uninspiring and the plot was as clear as mud. I didn't even bother to learn or remember the names bandied about. With so many gangster movies that are good, there has to be some bad ones. This is one.

Actually, I've watched it so many times because I have to write a paper on it for my film class, but what can I say?  I appreciate it more every time. The hat, the liquor, everything.  I think the thing I love best about this movie is the music.  The title music is beautiful and haunting, and I believe another post here mentioned the Danny Boy scene-- incredible stuff. While it's hard to understand Tom's motivations, I think that's what makes this film so great.By the way, keep your ears wide open; it's hard to tell because people talk so fast, but there is an explicit homosexual love triangle going on between Dane, Mink, and Bernie.  The hell you say!  But I can prove it:Tom says to Caspar, "There's always a wild card where love is involved," referring to Mink and Dane Mink uses a .22 -- a woman's gun Mink says defensively that he and Bernie are "Just, you know, amigos."Mink is Eddie Dane's "boy." The list goes on and on.  Anyway, look out for that.  I didn't catch it until my 3rd screening...sigh.

Quite simply the finest work to come from joel and Ethan Cohen in a hit and miss career ( thats being more miss lately than hit ). while Fargo is wonderful as well, it lacks the mesmerizing central character performances of this work. Gabriel Byrne is quite simply better than hes ever being. While John Tuturro's Machiavellian traitor is to put it mildly the best performance in a gangster movie since Pacino's, Michael Corleone. The support from Finney, Polito and Marcia Gay Harden is also top notch. the set pieces, the old style cagney like speak, the atmosphere of the piece and the complete and other cynicism of the film help to make it one of the most underrated and eloquent films of the last twenty years.

My Rating : 7/10Been meaning to watch 'Miller's Crossing' for a while and finally finished watching it. Coen Brothers know exactly what they are after and they capture it so effortlessly. They are true geniuses of the craft and it can be seen in every scene, every dialogue, every choice of music score, the costumers, the actors - just all-round artisans of the medium which they have perfected with surgical precision.This is a true classic and lives and breathes more like a novel which makes it a leisurely watch.No one's giving the high-hat to these rumpus makers that's for sure!

Although this film is directed by the Cohen brothers who are well known for comedy such as Raising Arizona and Oh,Brother Where Art Thou, it is violent and quite dark in places. Set in an anonymous American city during prohibition an Irish mob boss has the mayor and chief of police in his pocket but an up and coming Italian decides he's had enough of being second best and starts a war. The power behind the throne (Gabriel Byrne) finds himself in a web of deceit and danger as he plays both sides against the middle and faces a bullet to the head at any given second! This is a brilliant film and I cannot recommend it strongly enough. I just wish I had the ability with written words to fully convey how much I love this movie. That way others may also become fans.Mafia Film Website: www.mafiaflix.com Mafia Forums : www.mafiaflix.com/forums

The Coen Brothers gangster epic is a film masterpiece with a superb ensemble cast, sharp dialogue and a plot so twisty and turny it leaves your head spinning.  Better than their recent films Fargo and The Big Lebowski, Miller's crossing is an under-rated classic...

I am big fan of the Coen's and I think this tops their catalog. Everything about this film, the writing, the acting, the cinematography, the set, and the directing is sublime. Every one of the main characters could have been nominated for an Oscar as well as the screenplay, the directing, and the film as a whole. I've watched it many times and it never gets old. "That's what I like about you Tom...I never met anyone who made being a son of a b****, such a point of pride". Great lines all over this script

There's a lot of good things about this movie, but I just want to highlight that the writers, the Coen brothers, were sensible enough to use language, idioms and slang, appropriate to the times (the 1920s) and to the underworld that was its setting. Just a few examples: yegg, feeling daffy, to "queer" something. There were others, but I didn't keep a running tab though I wish I had for the purpose of this review. When a film is free of anachronisms in the setting or any other element, a viewer can settle into the cinematic experience without distraction and annoyance and be transported into the world the actors and director have created. This quality is rare in movies, but Miller's Crossing has it.

The Coen brothers are hit and miss.
Some movies are great, others like this one flop.
First of all, Gabriel Byrne is a fine supporting actor but he's no leading man.
Maybe if he had some help from the script he could have done a decent job here but the story never really coalesced.
The best actor in the movie was Jon Polito as Johnny Caspar.Save your time and money and find another movie.

reviews.review_title: This Underrated Film Requires Your Attention
reviews.content: The Coen Bros. go gangster. This can't miss, can it? Well, I suppose it could have, but it doesn't. In Miller's Crossing, Joel and Ethan Coen have once again hit one out of the park with their tale of 1930s mobsters doing battle with the police, and each other. Not an easy feat when you consider that another all-time great and much better known Mafia movie, Goodfellas, was released the same year. Not to mention the Untouchables just three years before. But Miller's Crossing demands its own place in the gangster spotlight, featuring Gabriel Byrne as the wise- ass wiseguy who can't quite decide whether he has it better under current bossman Albert Finney, or Finney's rival (and Coen Bros. mainstay), played perfectly by Jon Polito. Other than a mismatched romance between Byrne and love-interest Marcia Gay Harden, this film fires on all cylinders, and will surely creep into your thoughts for days on end. Byrne is effective with his typical nonchalance, but it's the supporting roles, which include John Turturro and Steve Buscemi, that give this film the depth that most attempts at conquering the genre lack. J.E. Freeman practically steals the film as "The Dane," Polito's unforgiving enforcer. Has it been done before? Yes. And arguably, it's been done better. But rarely is it done this well. See for yourself.

reviews.review_title: Seeing is believing. Or is it?
reviews.content: You don't need me to tell you what a great movie this is, but let me point out a particularly masterful scene anyway. It involves a dog, a wig, a boy, and a body. In one of the seedier parts of an altogether pretty seedy prohibition-era New Orleans, a nameless boy stumbles upon what seems to be a passed-out drunk propped up against the wall in a back alley. In an intricate interplay of shots and cuts, the dog makes the boy realize that the man he thought was drunk is in fact dead. The scene has no dialog, but displays and evokes a wealth of emotions that has since become one of the Coen brothers' hallmarks. At the same time, it touches on their philosophical trademark theme of perception and reality. In this respect, the alley scene is a variation of the movie's major mystery, a murder that may or may not be what it seems, depending on how (and when) you look at it. - Also watch out for Frances McDormand's nearly silent, uncredited appearance as the mayor's personal assistant in one of the final scenes.

I'm a great fan of the Coen brothers; ever since I saw "Blood Simple", I've eagerly awaited the release of each of their movies on home video (I'm not up to the sticky floors and noisy kids at our local cineplex).  I've had a couple of disappointments ("Barton Fink" and, especially, "The Big Lebowski"), but there's no accounting for personal taste.  In my opinion, "Fargo" has been their crowning accomplishment to date, but "Miller's Crossing" runs a close second.  Be forewarned, though, this is NOT another "Raising Arizona"; if you liked "Casino" and "Goodfellas", you'll probably love "Miller's Crossing"; if you found either of them heavy going, you might want to settle for a rerun of "The Usual Suspects".

reviews.review_title: Clever, twisty gangster with a great score
reviews.content: Re-watched this masterpiece of a movie with nothing much to add about how great it is except to mention that the score over the opening and ending credits is also memorable. The image of the hat blowing around the forest with this flute or whatever it is, leaves a lasting impression.

I love the Coen Brothers. They are artists. Masters of the cinema. In fact, when I first saw this, ask those years ago when it was first released, I absolutely loved it.But....I just watched it again and found the complex plot frustrating and the absurd nature of Byrne's relationships with all protagonists beyond parody.Sure, it's a stylish made movie, with great dialogue, a plethora of Coenesque caricatured characters and beautiful cinematography but I found it hard going.I feel as though I am blaspheming the almighty Coens by only giving it a 6. Sorry! 🙏

reviews.review_title: Revisionist '30s gangster flick a la Coen Bros.
reviews.content: MILLER'S CROSSING (1990) ***1/2  Gabriel Byrne, Albert Finney, Marcia Gay Harden, John Turturro, Jon Polito, J. E. Freeman, Steve Buscemi.  The Coen Brothers sterling salute to gangster flicks of the Thirties with grandstanding production values, trademark snarky humor and Barry Sonnenfeld's all-over-the-map photography encapsulates the small world of beat-upon Byrne as a henchman on the outs to influential mob leader Finney (clearly enjoying every second onscreen) and finds himself in the middle of a gang war while involved with a nowhere affair with his boss' skirt and the target of several setups/backstabbing/double-crosses.  Fine overall actingwise and one standout sequence after another (i.e. Turturro's `look into your heart' begging for his life and Finney's dispatching of would-be assassins to the tune of `Danny Boy' {!}).  Look sharp for filmmaker Sam Raimi as a smirking gunman.  And what exactly is up with the hat symbolism? I get it but many may not.

reviews.review_title: A great film from the Coen brothers
reviews.content: The Coen brother's lok at Irish mafia is considered by many to be a mini-masterpiece. I enjoyed the film a lot and thought it was great but in my opinion they did not achieve the term "masterpiece" until Barton Fink a year later. But anyhow, this film was great too, I can see why many love it, great performances, written very well. It is very different from other Coen films though, i thought it was much more brutal and Tarantino-esquire than ony other Coen film. But it worked, a great cast especially Turturro and Gabriel Byrne, as well as Polito and Finney. The entire cast was perfect in this film and really made it work, a great atmosphere and also nice cinematography from Barry Sonnenfeld. -- IMDb Rating: 7.9, my rating: 9/10

reviews.review_title: In my top 5 Coen brothers movies
reviews.content: "Miller's Crossing" is a mob classic that every fan of serious movie should watch. Coming from innovative Coen brothers, this movie will stick with you because of its brilliant lines, twists, acting and directing. There isn't much to say about the actors, top class names like Byrne, Finney, Turturro, Gay Harden, Buscemi and in here great Polito, speak for themselves just like brilliant script from Coen's. Also music is one of the reasons why I gave this movie excellent grade; version of 'Danny Boy' is just outstanding!!! To compare this movie with other gangster movies is all right but not to untouchable "The Godfather". Although I have a great sympathy to one of the best Coen brothers movies ever, I must also say that it doesn't touches sky high Coppola's "The Godfather". But "Miller's Crossing" is a movie that everyone should view and judge for themselves.

reviews.review_title: Original, gritty, and of course, humorous.
reviews.content: Tom Regan, (Gabriel Byrne) the adviser of Prohibition-era crime boss Leo, (Albert Finney) tries to keep the peace between him and a rival crime boss, playing both sides when the war heats up, forcing him to make decisions that stab both sides in the back.A film with realistic grittiness to it. The impressive art direction, the performances, and the violent nature of each scene really drag you deep into the film's setting. Marcia Gay Harden, while not having much of a role in this, gives a stunning performance. Also includes the Coen debut of John Turturro, who does an amazing job for a small role, an underrated actor who will go on to do Barton Fink and O Brother, Where Art Thou.A very unpredictable piece that keeps you on your feet. You feel like you're fighting alongside these characters, and just when you think they'll do something, they do something else.Not one of the Coen's better films, but very interesting nonetheless.

The Dane and Bernie were highlights in the twisty gang flick.  As always, the Coen brothers make excellent films with snappy dialogue, great characters, and technically perfect filmmaking.  Look for all the familiar faces, because they are there.  Excellent flick, should be watched if you love gangster or Coen brothers films.  Note, sometimes the movie seemed sort of cartoonish to me.  Not that I am complaining, but see if you notice it too.

"So take your flunkie and dangle." I love that line, spoken by crime boss Albert Finney to underboss Jon Polito in Miller's Crossing. This is a neatly woven, gorgeous film, written almost a little too smooth.Gabriel Byrne finds his perfect role here as the noir-ish troubled loner who lives by a code and despises himself when he breaks it for anything (love, friendship). Albert Finney is Leo, his boss, whose love of Vera (recent Oscar Winner Marcia Gay Harden in her fist role) has clouded his judgement and caused his empire to crash down. The movie follows Byrne walking a thin line of lies and loyalties, but to whom.Jon Polito and JE Freeman make perfect pair as Italian underboss Johnny Casper and his henchman Eddie Dane. Dane is the violent, loyal second in command who really carries many of the films best scenes.
I highly recommend this film. It is very enjoyable and the kind of movie that cries out to be watched over and over again. See the Coen brothers before they were perfect (Fargo), but still better than most.
***1/2 out of ****.

'Miller's Crossing', the third film from the Coen brothers, opens with a monologue from the pig- like Johnny Caspar (Jon Polito). He is discussing ethics, and is also trying to see if Irish crime boss Leo (Albert Finney) will do anything if Caspar were to take someone out. After seeing that Leo would, Caspar leaves along with his brutal henchman Eddie Dane (J.E. Freeman), and in a sense has threatened Leo by saying he's 'sick of the high hat'. Leo's advisor Tom Reagan (Gabriel Byrne) disagrees with Leo's decision, and knows he refused Caspar because he is dating the target's sister, Verna (Marcia Gay Harden). Things began to get messy as a war begins to take shape, and Tom is afraid Leo will not be able to hold up against Caspar anymore. More-so, the target Bernie Bernbaum (John Turturro) begins to meet more with Tom, causing him problems. The main factor in 'Miller's Crossing' is the superb writing. The dialogue is quite refreshing and flows extremely well, (also see 'The Man Who Wasn't There' for an example of this). The characters are individual, living, breathing human beings and most of them want different things. The dialogue comes alive the most in several scenes between Tom and Leo. The performances are also good too, most notably Finney as the like-able Leo, a kind man who doesn't realize what trouble he's starting for everyone. Also worth mentioning are Bryne as the somewhat cold Tom, a man who is extremely intelligent and knows what he's doing. The supporting cast puts in some refined work as well, Polito as the temperamental Caspar, Turturro as the slick Bernbaum, and a nicely done cameo by Steve Buscemi as Mink, one of Bernie's friends. The photography by frequent Coen collaborator is also very nicely done, with some very beautiful shots. The action scenes in the film are also great to watch and the music by also frequent collaborator Carter Burwell is a nice touch too. Joel Coen also did a good job directing, making the scenes work out dynamically and getting the viewer into the film all the while building up momentum and throwing some surprises to the audience. The style of the film also was a different approach for them, it came after the dark and suspenseful thriller 'Blood Simple' and the whacked out comedy 'Raising Arizona', and instead transferred to a more smooth looking feel. 'Miller's Crossing' is definitely a must see for all fans of the Coen brothers, a nicely styled little masterpiece and a refreshing look at the mob of the 30's. 10/10

The CoBros made a movie with all style no substance. It's claustrophobic , not shots are wide enough to see a real world. I saw it as a dream...the hat blowing away dream Tommy talked about. I didn't mind the hammy acting all around, or even the boilerplate lot. It just is nothing, almost like a contractual agreement movie.

I'll make my comments short and sweet since so many others have managed to express what makes this film a true Noir masterpiece.I've watched it about a dozen times now since its release and I rarely watch even a good film more than once or twice. This one just has so many layers that make it interesting, and I don't think you can catch all the witty rapid-fire dialog after one or two viewings.For me, there is one scene that I rewind and watch over and over again because I think it's truly one of the great cinematic orchestrations ever: I speak of the Albert Finney (Wow, what a consistent pro he is!) scene in which he's home relaxing with a cigar and "Danny Boy" (the definitive Irish-American anthem) playing on the Victrola near his bed. Then all he** breaks loose and we see Finney/Leo dashing under the bed as he senses the gangsters slipping up the stairs, dispatching them quickly after carefully extinguishing the cigar. He then grabs a sheet, swings out the second floor window as the house burns down, grabs the confiscated Tommy gun and dispatches the gangster army one by one with great precision while standing outside in his robe and slippers. Satisfied that he's vanquished the enemy, he tenderly pulls out the cigar from his robe pocket, torches it up again, and proceeds to enjoy the final refrains of Danny Boy as the house burns. Amazing scene! Not only was it incredibly well-constructed by the Coens, but Finney plays it with such a sense of "just another day at the office" that you can't help wanting to light up a cigar of your own to enjoy it with him.I can't get that scene out of my head and have even dreamed about it. A few years ago, I would have rated this film around an 8, but after watching it and the entire, almost-perfect film repeatedly, I have to concede it's become an all-time favorite, and I'd rate it 11 if I could! Great cast (particularly Finney, Byrne, and Harden), great screenplay, fantastic cinematography, and the Coen Brothers are the only team that could have pulled this one off so well: about the best in American film.

reviews.review_title: A beautiful mix of gangster and film-noir
reviews.content: I really, really dug it. Everything just worked for me. The meshing of gangster with film-noir just seems right, and the fantastic dialogue combined with the twisty (but not too twisty) story makes for one helluva screenplay. Byrne is terrific here, making his protagonist both likable and unlikeable, switching from charming and witty to morally questionable to downright evil and back without a problem. I loved the way he played every character in the film, and basically drove all the events of the story; the fact that we connect with him, and then feel his terror when he thinks he's been caught, but then revolt him when he spins his webs, is just brilliant. I also liked the undercurrent of really dark comedy that runs throughout the film. Technically, it's superb, and for pure entertainment, you can't do much better. A real treat.

reviews.review_title: Some of the acting lets it down
reviews.content: This is a fairly typical movie about 1930's American gangsters. It's not a bad story, but you won't see anything new. The main reason where I believe it fails is with the leader actors portrayal of the main character. I generally like Gabriel Byrnes acting. However, on this occasion his portrayal of a gangster seems to be almost a bad copy from a b grade 1930s movie. The supporting cast do quite a good job and carry the film. Could have been much better.

reviews.review_title: Awesome movie! - but cold and cruel
reviews.content: I watched this movie without knowing its from the Coen Brothers. I am a huge fan of their movies - and it surprised me a lot reading their names on IMDb after watching the movie. This movie is one of their less funny movies (even though it still has the typical absurd humor). It's nonetheless one of their greatest movies. It's pretty much flawless. Great story, intelligent conversations (might have been too artificial sometimes), great atmosphere, great music, great characters and perfectly fitting actors.****Spoileralert****Still, I am not sure if I want to rate this movie with 9 or 10 points. It's somewhere in between for me. While everything in this movie was pretty much perfect, I was missing some sort of sympathetic figure. There was no single good guy in this movie. It shouldn't make a movie worse, but it's sort of hard for me to evoke feelings of tense excitement if I barely care for the actors. This movie is far from good and evil. If you like that, this movie might become one of your favorite. If not, you might have a foul aftertaste in your mouth after watching this one.****Spoileralert ending****I have decided to rate this movie with 9 points. Simply because I find that there are better Coen Brothers movies out there. Especially more wicked ones.

I love the Coen Brothers, they have created some of the most diverse original films i've ever seen. Millers Crossing seems at first to be a homage to old pulp comics of the 30's, Prohibition setting, shoot-outs with Tommy-guns, anti heroes with attitude and dames. But this is so much more than that, its about friendship, sacrifice, saving yourself and most importantly its about a man chasing his hat.

"Miller's Crossing" is a film that carries us back to a time when crime was classier and simpler. A time when a good head and a smart plan could take you to the top, if you wanted to be there. Our main character here, Tom Regan, decides he doesn't. Maybe too smart, Tom gets mixed up with the boss' girl. He never shows disloyalty; he just does what he wants because he can. With a few memorably awesome scenes, the story moves relatively slow until we are finally shown the portrait of a man who knows his time and his place. The story takes us through a month or so in the life of Tom as he plays all sides of a hairy situation to his advantage."Miller's Crossing" suffers from one or two sub-standard actors. This would be fine in most Coen brothers' films, but here, it really shows because the film is meant to be taken so seriously. Marcia Gay Harden is terrible as the gangster moll girlfriend. She hams it up and overacts. I thought the guy who played Johnny Caspar was bad also. Too funny and he should have been more serious. It didn't fit.All in all, "Miller's Crossing" is a well-done piece that has a wonderful ending that makes all the bumps in the road getting there worthwhile.8 out of 10, kids.

reviews.review_title: Pay close attention and don't miss a beat in this masterpiece!
reviews.content: Miller's Crossing is probably one of the most under-appreciated films in the Coen Brothers pantheon of classics. This story of double, triple, and quadruple crossing is quite possibly one of the best pieces of cinema ever produced. The writing and timing and pace of the film are flawless. The acting is wonderful by Gabriel Byrne as the main character. With perfect supporting work by Albert Finney, Marcia Gay Harden, John Turturro, Steve Buscemi, Jon Polito, Mike Starr, Al Mancini, and especially J.E. Freeman as Eddie Dane the ruthless hitman who's onto every move of Gabriel Byrne. Great character development and flowing story keep this really interesting with great scene after great scene. A good score that features the classic Irish folk tune "Oh Danny Boy" in probably one of the best scenes in any movie ever. A great concept story of fictional 1920's gangsters at war. Really powerful. Great cinematography. Not much bad can be said about this true jewel. 10 out of 10.

I may have rated this film a near 7 in earlier years, but each time I watch it, I am impressed with each aspect of film production that is involved with the final product.Such a great sense of timing, the dialog is beautiful and wonderful between the 4 main participants great casting all around music is so important and well introduced setting is present visually and mentally consistentit doesn't really drop away as the film progresses. the film making marvels anything contemporary and any it draws from.there are many different types of films that we all can enjoy, but this film gives the viewer so much in so many different realms, it should be viewed, reviewed and appreciated for the fine performances in every aspect that film-making contains.I've seen other comparisons with this and the Godfather. They are different films and different film experiences. Miller's is much more film noir and it doesn't purport to be more than that, except in its excellent portrayal of that genre. Wonderful film each time it's watched.consistent and beautiful

"Miller's crossing" is a neo noir of the Coen brothers. It did not perform well at the box office, but in later years was an art house hit on DVD.Maybe the complicated plot was responsible for the disappointing performance on the big screen. After all on a DVD you can revisit crucial twists of the plot if necessary. Honestly, I don't believe this explenation. Complicated plots are nothing special for film noirs. Look at "The big sleep" (1946, Howard Hawks). The story is almost incomprensible, but the film nevertheless was received well.The problem in my opinion is not that the film is too complicated but that it is too artificial. It seems as if the Coen brothers were making a film for film aficionados and not for the average moviegoer. Look at the opening scene with a discussion about business ethics within the maffia business. A clear reference to the opening scene of "The Godfather" (1972, Francis Ford Coppola) but that can only be appreciated if you have seen this film (and other films the film is refering to). Roger Ebert was right when he wrote:"The pleasures of the film are largely technical. It is likely to be most appreciated by movie lovers who will enjoy its resonance with films of the past".

While the Coen Brothers' movies are almost always entertaining and unpredictable, this is the one where everything just comes together perfectly. Great acting, amazing cinematography, and a storyline that rewards repeated viewing. Run, don't walk to see this movie. Why isn't this on DVD??

reviews.review_title: One Of My Favorite Film From The 90s.
reviews.content: This is definetly a film that should be viewed by all. It is suberb and very stylish in it's storytelling of a heartless mobster who goes by him own rules, with no loyalties to anyone. Gabriel Byrne is perfect as the jaded, chief aide to Albert Finney, who gives the best performance he ever given in any movie.(The 'Danny Boy' scene is one of the best moments in filmdom history) Ultra slick dialouge, matched with unforgetable characters, make this a movie to watch again and again. Joe Polito gives an incredible performance, as a rival mobster who wants to take over the racket that Finney and Byrne have. J.E. Freeman is especially powerful in the role as his right hand man, The Dane. Great cinematography, brilliant settings, and of course the razor-edged stylized directing all make this dark, brooding, very atmospheric work the Coen Brothers best movie.P.S. I have a fun drinking game, every time someone says, "Jesus Tom." during the movie, you have to do a shot of Irish Whiskey!

The Coen bros. previous efforts (BLOOD SIMPLE, RAISING ARIZONA) showed their capability of producing films in a small budgeted quirky landscape, but MILLER'S CROSSING did much to prove that they had a unique vision in serious film making. This film set the tone for the bros. more dramatic projects to come: BARTON FINK, FARGO, the talent heavy missed opportunity MAN WHO WASN'T THERE, and the high-concept HUDSUCKER PROXY. The true source of genius in this film is the look. Barry Sonnenfeld's photography, and Dennis Gassner's sumptuous production design (you can almost feel the woodstain soaking into the paneling in Leo's office) help to make this one of the most visually distinct films in recent memory. The pan shot of the tree tops, the hat in the wind, the shoot out, all great scenes developed with a resonating style. Carter Burwell's score helps to create a bucolic aural backdrop to the on-screen happenings. The performances are all A-list: Gabriel Byrne as Tom Reagan, the film's oft abused protagonist; John Turturro's scene at the crossing is worth the price of admission; Albert Finney's Leo is wonderfully single-minded and bullish; Jon Polito's rival gangster is scene stealing; Marcia Gay Harden is perfect in the film's only center stage (if underdeveloped) female role; and J.E. Freeman as the Dane is chilling and nuanced.The plot of the film is not perfect, however. It revolves around Tom Reagan's machinations (many of which seem to happen by chance or dumb-luck) to help Leo, his boss and friend, out of a difficult situation, involving love, betrayal and gangland confrontations. The plot, which becomes a bit more lucid upon repeated viewings, is helped along by the quick and fun dialogue (terms such as "twist", "dangle", "insky/outsky", "yeg", etc) and keeps things moving. The absence of sex and foul language help make the scenes of intense violence even more so, by allowing the Coen bros. to make these instances more graphic. I must admit that I am not that big a fan of the bros. more recent popular work (THE BIG LEBOWSKI was a funny-in-places surreal romp and O BROTHER, I think, is their worst film to date), and I choose to look back at MILLER'S CROSSING as setting the standard. I'm sure by now that you are bored of listening to me gush about this movie, check it out and decide for yourself. It at least is a gorgeous pulp drama with clever dialogue; I think it is one of the best films of the 1990's and I tend to distrust anyone who says otherwise. There have been instances where, having found myself in the same room as someone such as this, I will transfer the money I have on me to my sock at the first available opportunity...for certainly they would cut me off at the heels if there were two bits in it for them. 10/10

reviews.review_title: Coolest, fast-paced and most gripping gangster movie I've seen...
reviews.content: ..."Miller's Crossing" is the Coen's Godfather.  It is cool, gripping, suspenseful and even funny.  Most think the plot revolves around the love triangle between crime boss Leo (Albert Finney), his      (Marcia Gay Harden) and his advisor Tom Reagan (Gabriel Byrne), but they'd be wrong. The real story focuses on Reagan's falling out with Leo and his joining rising boss Johnny Caspar (Jon Polito), but it is still unclear where Reagan's real loyalty belongs.You'd think it was impossible for movies to get this good, honestly.  The performances and script make the movie.  Byrne created what's definitely my favorite anti-hero in the character of Tom Reagan, his manor cold and his cause menacing.  Harden makes a character you love to     , and Finney is cool as the childish Leo.  Of course, other great performances come from Polito, who's Caspar is Oscar worthy.  Also, J.E. Freeman creates a great villain as Caspar's henchman Eddie Dane, and John Turturro does a great job as the slippery Bernie Burnbaum.Another thing worth mentioning is the gripping fast-pace.  It reminds one of The Godfather: Part II, but I must admit that even that had some slow scenes.Miller's Crossing has none, 9/10.

This one is a puzzle. The movie is admittedly stylish and a great physical production. It features smart dialogue, occasional humor (sometimes broad, sometimes not), and fine performances from Marcia Gay Harden, Albert Finney, and Gabriel Byrne. It pays homage to the gangster picture of the 1930's and 1940's and to the pulp fiction of Dashiel Hammett, and gangsters, like grifters, are as American as cherry pie. So far, so good. On the other hand, the plot, with its crosses and double-crosses and double-double-crosses, is virtually undiagrammable. No wonder the Coens found completing their script so difficult. Is "Miller's Crossing," as a perceptive reviewer suggests, really a meditation on honor, friendship, and ethics? Is it, as another reviewer asserts, really about "chasing your own hat," that is, about seeking and finding independence? From a mob boss? From a two-timing moll? Without giving up killing? Maybe so, but it's hard to take pleasure in such rarefied notions when the storyline here is so tangled. "Miller's Crossing," with its production values, holds the viewer's attention from beginning to end, all right, but the plot is driven by the rapidly changing machinations of Tom Reagan (Byrne), the lieutenant to Irish mob boss Leo O'Bannon (Finney). Those machinations, springing from the mind of a thug and not of a Nobel Prize winner or Wall Street derivatives specialist, are intended to be realistic and plausible, and -- more than that -- convincing to other thugs, and they plainly aren't. 7.5 out of 10.

Yet another stylish but relatively empty Cohen Bros study of the wretchedly brutal lives of worthless underworld gangsters. Direction, characters, and dialogue are as measured as they are familiar and seem to be copying many gangster flicks that went before it. Take away the obviously slick scene set- ups and it's just a shell that's strung together in order to cram in as many killings, bashings and double crosses as three or four other movies just like it.The movie's main character (Byrne) is somewhat like a cartoon character, who gets knocked down several flights of stairs, bashed so badly (and often) that it's amazing he can ever stand again but the next day he's on the street looking fresh as a daisy. The only wound ever visibly inflicted is a cracked lip (that he's had since the movie started!). It's all reminiscent of a Sergio Lorne spaghetti western, the type these movie makers would have grown up watching.Fans will not see the flaws through being blinded by the trendy stylistics but judging by the poor box-office returns, many others were not being so fooled. Carter Burwell's score, adapted from a Celtic classic is most effective but deserves a better subject. The last scene, this time reminiscent of a far better Carol Reed classic, also features a Hat scene that looks like it belonged in a dark, Disney remake of the story of Johnny Fedora and Alice Blue Bonnet. A good cast wasted in more over the top nasty silliness.

Take the most well-known Coen films such as 'The Big Lebowski,' 'Fargo,' and the recent 'Oh Brother;' remove the comedic aspects, creativity, and uniquely intriguing characters, and you'll have a good idea of what 'Miller's Crossing' is. This is the Coen brothers attempt at a plot movie. They put all their eggs into one basket and if the basket breaks they're out of luck. Personally, I thought the movie was so-so. It added little to the gangster genre. The only thing keeping me attached to the movie was the fact that I am a big Coen fan and was interested in seeing their take on gangster film.
If you've seen 'The Big Lebowski' a few times, you'd be amazed at how complex the plot is because there are so many other perks to keep you distracted. In 'Miller's Crossing,' it is plot and nothing else. If you don't like the plot you don't like the movie. I think I was most disappointed with the homogeneity of the characters. Everyone from the girl, to the police chief, to the mayor, to each and every gangster is shown as cold, calculating, and arrogant - just like every gangster film. Without novel characters or dark humor, this movie looked devoid of its Coen-ness.

reviews.review_title: Just took too long to go about its business. Why watch this when you can watch the real thing (The Godfather)?
reviews.content: It wastes an hour and fifteen minutes before it gets interesting. Then very quickly gets boring again.I don't like Gabrielle Byrne, I don't like Marcia Gay Harden, I don't like Albert Finney; the music matches the irish characters, but turns the action into a tele-movie. Like many Coen efforts every moment plays out too slowly. Every moment drags. Its tone is so only half funny you're always wondering whether its a parody or serious: and it ends up not effective as either.The cinematography was the biggest disappointment, and the biggest factor in making this looking like a tele-movie trying to do a gangster movie. From Barry Sonnenfeld, who everybody talks about, I expected something flashy. I expected Godfather-quality evocative pools of light: what I got was the Coens' usual cartoony over-bright, too-colourful look, which suits a gangster story about as well as the music does.The gems are few and far between: the scene where the little boy pulls the wig off the corpse twenty minutes in is a gem. Steve Buscemi. John Turturro. When Turturro returns at one hour fifteen.This was a laboured, uninteresting movie experience for me.4/10.

reviews.review_title: Superb, Dark, Complex, Irreverent Gangster Drama
reviews.content: It took me too long to catch this classic, tough gangster drama. The characters are quite vivid and unique, although barely likable. The film feels like an artistic rendering from the first image and always keeps you guessing. Not the best gangster film, but a profoundly unique cinematic voyage into the underworld.It's dark and long and not a feel-good movie, so be prepared. But it's easy to see why this film remains in the IMDb top 250 15 years after its release.Gabriel Byrne's inspired performance makes you wonder why he never hit the big time. And Albert Finney is like that friendly gangster uncle you never knew you had.Chris X. Moloney 2005

If there's one thing you can say about the Coen brothers, it's that they're a pair of pretty original filmmakers. And the films they make are a blend of multiple styles and genres which are channeled into one project: like nothing you've seen before.The film is set during the Prohibition era, a setting which can often be pitfall for synthetic style. While the Coen's clearly give this film a particular style-which isn't entirely based on absolute reality-it doesn't feel overly injected or manufactured. And though this flair isn't completley based in corporality, there's enough to it that at least makes it work if you're open to their unique mannerisms.Such as how picture is a gangster film with many trademarks of the type, yet it hardly feels like one in some ways. While it does contain things like murder and deceit, instead of the hard-edge style you might automatically associate with it, the film has a suprisingly mellow tone.And an inscrutable plot.Perhaps the picture's fatal flaw is that too much is happening too quickly and too often to give you time to comprehend it all. And no amount of texture, acting or anything else can make a story intresing that's so hard to follow.

I don't usually like prohibition-era gangster movies, but this one is an exception. It's a Coen Brothers film in the best sense, a hint at the great films they were going to make later on.Gabriel Byrne dominates this movie with one of his best performances ever; he is joined by a superb cast with not a single weak actor. John Turturro, Jon Polito and Albert Finney stand out most, but this is really an ensemble movie where everything fits in place.9/10, highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: "You're so goddamn smart. Except you ain't."
reviews.content: Contrary to what Blackavaar says in his comment (opposing what Pete the Geek said in his comment)... this film may not just be a comedy, but it is not a pure crime flick either. Jon Polito's character for instance: this is not a comedy character? Gettaheyouttahey! And there are plenty of other comedy characters here, as well, as there also are some rather funny scenes (check the confrontation in the warehouse, the interactions between Johnny Caspar and his son). I'm not sure what the Coens intended this to be (the only genres here on IMDb are crime, drama and thriller), but perhaps they had some 'black comedy' in mind, also.Of course, the mixing of comedy with the crime (and drama) genre doesn't have to be a problem, but for me, it just doesn't work here. In that respect, this a rare Coens film, because it is actually their 'worst'... though it still is a more than enjoyable flick, let's call it an over the top ode to the good ol' crime and film noir genre. And there where the drama element peaks - Bernie on his knees in the woods, pleading for dear life with Tom, and later when they return to the woods again, and Tom is just 'sick' of it, and, finally, when Tom decides he has no heart left for Bernie) - the film is simply brilliant. It really makes me wish they hadn't put in those extravagant comedy elements.Other than that, 'Miller's...' shows some terrific acting, some tasteful costumes and settings (although a couple of trees steal and a hat the show), and some clever and funny dialogues - unfortunately, a great amount of others didn't work for me at all.A good 7 out of 10.

This film is ridiculous. The most painful part of the film is when each actor opens their mouth. Give me a break...all of the brothers films are much better than this one. The only reason you morons like this is because it is a "oldschool gang flick" with all the token scenes you would expect. This does not hold a candle to any true film depicting the era. I will admit that the scene where the hit men come to kill Leo is pretty amazing, but that is about as good as it gets. All you who put this in a top category need to go watch some real gangster films. PS - Gabriel Bryne is the SAME character in every single movie...but it only works in Usual Suspects...that is it.

reviews.review_title: A defining masterpiece of modern cinema
reviews.content: Review: Millers Crossing is the Coen brothers greatest film to date and can even be foreseen as a modern classic. It's wide range of skilled direction as well as top form storytelling inspires from it's epic opener to it's resounding finale. The Coen brothers have mixed all the aspects of great movie making onto one harrowingly brilliant film. It's quality and style only seeks to exist in a film like this one. The genre has been swiftly tackled by the likes of Sergio Leone (Once Upon a Time in America) and Martin Scorse (The Departed) but the Coen brother's Millers Crossing is one of those defining examples of great acting and in-expendable pure direction all brought to one film.Verdict: A not to be missed classic.

Crazy how this movie didn't get any Oscar nominations. This gangster flick has to go down has one of the greatest ones yet. Like the godfather this movie brings real class to the mob world and the Danny Boy scene I have to say is one of the greatest I've seen in all of cinema, I totally recommend you watch this film if you're a true movie lover and a fan of gangster movies.

I was surprised to see only 200-some user reviews for this film, which I agree is definitely one of the Coen brothers' best works, if not The Best.I also had to check the film's specs, as I couldn't remember (saw it a few months ago) whether it was in black and white or not. The film specs say Color. If that's right, it gives the most dazzlingly gorgeous impression of the play of light and shadow that makes black and white so beautiful, without actually being in monochrome.The actors and dialogue and plot are all unforgettable as well, with the trademark humour of these directors providing some great moments.
The cast, the story, the script were all spectacular. This is one of my favorite gangster movies of all time. I've seen it numerous times and never get tired of it.

Very thinly plotted and just above average acted. Some mix ups and double crossings from some of the mafiosi crossing paths, but we don't really care about any of them really, no background on them, just some vague talk on game fixing. The minor character of Casper is a joy to watch and there are some brilliant understated comedic lines from him, but the others are all paper thinly written and forgettable. I don't like Gabriel Byrne, he's not much of an actor, but he's half decent here, just barely. Marcia Gay Harden is atrocious though. They are making this fuss about this plain broad, the guys who own every working girl in town. Give me a break. It's very easy to tell she got the part from the window, good connections though I ll grant her that.What else. Ah, again it proves that most film viewers are morons if they proclaim this thinly written and forgettable story as a masterpiece. Fairwell my lovely is a great film, and so is the other raymond carver film they shot, the big sleep, but this is just trite. Of course its not the disgrace with Stuart Cox characters that the Cohen's write these days (malcovich in burn after reading) but it ain't good either. Of course as per usual some brilliant Cohen wit every thirty minutes or so, and the usual great cinematography but that's about it.I am giving it four stars while it should be five or six just because I had high hopes for it and didn't meet the expectations at all.A very disappointing film all in all. It really bugs me how a film like this gets such high grades, a film so vacant and soul less as this, a gangster farce, and vapid in its own genre really. Who cares about a half wit small time gangster who never as much as emotes to anything in the film, at least give us some clever twists here, everything is so boringly predictable. Well, the Cohen's being the jewry they are got all the funds they could to keep making more films after this and luckily we did get a masterpiece in Lebowski. But it seems lately their films are worse than millers' crossing, very stupid crap they make nowadays, just utter farce garbage...shame really cause they are some of the people that are really doing cinema in the states. Let's hope they get some of that talent back, because I am sure they too know it that burn after reading and the other one with clooney and zeta jones are phone ins.

Gone are the days when an ultra violent exercise like Miller's Crossing would earn an X rating. The film attempts a more realistic approach to gangland Chicago during the 1930s. If you can imagine those old George Raft pictures, with the addition of modern permissiveness for onscreen displays of real gut wrenching violent action, then you have this. I just can't get past the violence this film delivers. Its too much, not in quantity but in quality, and just stays with you in a bad way. And I don't think that is a talent moviemaking-wise. In fact, I think it would be rather simple to do. But all of the major scenes that involve death bother me greatly, to the point where I won't watch it again. The fact is, that this stuff didn't or doesn't happen in real life. So why do we make films like this? I mean think about it, is this any more redeeming than filming people having consensual sex? As the conventional wisdom answers this question for me, I feel secure in declaring us as humans, a warped species.

Twice in my life I've left a theater feeling awed by the intelligence of what I've seen.  Once was on Broadway after seeing Tom Stoppard's "Arcadia." The other time was my first viewing of "Miller's Crossing."Yes, the cinematography is gorgeous.  Yes, the production design is lush and rich in masculine colors.  Yes, Carter Burwell's music is haunting and perfectly suited to the story.  And Yes, the performances are all spot on perfect.But I had to see this movie several times to figure out what happened and why.  Gabriel Byrne's character of Tom is as complex a character as you're likely to see on screen.  As Vera says to him at one point, "Christ, Tom, all ya had to do was ask."  And yet, he is someone who is incapable of asking for any sort of favor, whether it's from Leo, Vera, anyone.  And the mechanisms he puts into play to resolve his problems are complex, interwoven and not a little self-destructive.  He someone who is capable of taking a punch (and he takes plenty) and yet seemingly incapable of delivering one. Ultimately he gets what he wants and loses everything he values.The Coen brothers said this was a story about men in hats.  And clearly it is, but what the hell does that mean?  Tom is clearly "chasing his hat" which means he is seeking something that escapes him.  But he refuses to ackowlege that he's chasing it, and by refusing to accept that there are things he wants, he loses that which matters most to him.The Coens are routinely criticized for being brainiac manipulators of their characters, more concerned with the conceits and gimics of their gags than with the humanity of their characters.  What a crock.  They are not maudlin sentimentalists and thank God for that.  The fact is they have a great deal of compassion for people who don't seem to have any themselves.  Jerry Lundegard in "Fargo" was clearly the character they felt the most for and his increasingly desperate and tragic actions were the heart of that film, not Frances McDormand's chirpy sheriff.The Coens make movies as well as anyone.  They write scintilating dialogue, they use the camera as well as anyone, they use color like a painter.  But they have always been shortchanged by people like Owen Gleiberman of EW because they "have no heart."  Like Tom Regan in "Miller's Crossing" they have a heart, but you have to look to find it and it might be a troubled one.
Imagine if the coen brothers were from the silent epoch; I'm glad we don't have to.

reviews.review_title: "Miller's Crossing" Is A Homage To Classic Noir, Whilst Consisting Of Every Element Which Makes A Coen Brother Film Instantly Recognisable
reviews.content: Much of the Coen's films frequently contain evident homages to classic crime-capers, from The Big Lebowski being an ode to The Big Sleep, to Miller's Crossing being a homage to long-established American noir, such as The Glass Key. Miller's Crossing is the film which indisputably established the Coens' talent as a pair of film-makers who would go down in history, following their prior success of Blood Simple and Raising Arizona. The tangled web, fuming with deceit, betrayal and vengeance has now become a fundamental trademark for the Coens' films.Gabriel Byrne performs as Tom Reagan, an adviser for the mob, who thinks before he speaks, yet is prepared to speak his mind, whatever the cost, something he learns is dangerous in the company of the men he is surrounded by. He is essentially a man who lives in a world surrounded by crime, while being a criminal himself, nonetheless he does not attempt find trouble, but rather trouble finds him due to his fraternising with countless mobsters and the dangerous use of his tongue. Due to the frequent swaying of Tom's loyalty it is inevitable that he is going to make enemies; eventually "changing sides" and turning-the-tables on his long-time friend and business partner Leo (played by Albert Finney). Leo is the king of the city, yet because of a disagreement and rejection of a "hit" proposed by fellow mob-boss Johnny Casper (Jon Polito), Tom and Leo fall out. Set around America's prohibition in the 1930s, the film charts the tale of gangsters abusing a corrupt system of injustice and moral decay.Tom Reagan is an immoral man who is striving to gain a meaning to his unethical lifestyle, attempting to balance his apprehension, guilt and moral-values. If problems such as never knowing who to trust and choosing whether to "dispose" of a friend are not enough, he is also subconsciously seeking to build a relationship, something which is painfully difficult under his circumstances. He is struggling to find values beneath his brutal lifestyle of criminal activity. Tom Reagan has "friends" as such, but most of them are with him for protection, or in some cases, the other way round. Acting is one of the countless aspects of flawlessness in Miller's Crossing, considering everyone from Gabriel Byrne, to Albert Finney, to John Turturro and Jon Polito give career-defining performances of enthusiastic supremacy.It is fact that the characters of Miller's Crossing are all intelligent people, in some way, even unexpectedly. Everyone is in search of something and hold some sort of initiative and hidden prerogative behind their decisions. Written with an almighty gusto, the characters roll off the screen from both the hard-edged, bitter script and the unsentimental, glaringly robust performances. Miller's Crossing, as with most Coen Brother films follows a dialogue-driven narrative, invigorated by dark humour, blunt, snappy one-liners and quick-fire conversations which feel humanly laboured and distant. All this helps to create the cold ambiance of the film; capturing the period through convincing set-pieces, props and costumes of the time, giving the film that extra level of accuracy.As expected with a film of this kind, Miller's Crossing has scenes brimming with grandiose violence, which is blood-thirsty and brutal in capturing the irrational foolishness of a human's lust for brutality. Shot in a method which is almost fantasy-like, the now-timeless imagery will become lodged in your mind for eternity. The cinematography is moody, smoky, edgy and cold. Miller's Crossing successfully captures the meaning behind a scene through evocative environments, which etch varied tones of emotion into the viewer. Many of the film's key themes are told through metaphorical imagery, a key image being the hat, a metaphor which is open to interpretation. The film benefits from morose lighting and shadows, emphasising elements such as the furniture and architecture of buildings. Camera angles are also a leading importance for Miller's Crossing, with moments of uncomfortable, gawky positioning, serving to accentuate the thorny, paradoxical plot. The use of zooms, slow fades, quick-cuts and stretching shots make addition to the film's stunning technical achievements. Gracefully placed editing alleviates the low-brow humour and tension, and not forgetting the beautifully poetic score, which fits the characters' distant desires.Complicated, high-strung, cold-blooded storytelling, which is unlike anything you will ever see. Miller's Crossing does stick to its film-noir and "gangster movie" roots, but ultimately it is an illustration of an individual's principles and the senseless violence of gangsters struggling for power. Twists and turns can be rarely executed with such perfection, Miller's Crossing offers viewers much to ponder, meaning revisiting such an underrated masterpiece is obligatory.

Miller's Crossing is a popcorn movie for intellectuals. Full of the usual Coen Brother sparkle - colorful dialogue, creative imagery, and otherworldly feel - the intricate plot is also wonderfully constructed. Paced like a mystery, we follow Tom Reagan as he makes a series of odd choices that seem, one by one, to be the wrong choices but ultimately are the right ones. The Coens keep pulling out formulaic tricks, particularly the one where Tom is ALMOST done in for several times before some last minute twist of fate saves his life. This kind of thing can be exasperating for a chronic film-goer, but the way the Coen's have set it up we are so involved in the story that anything incongruous with reality is immaterial- the Coen's have made their own reality.

My favourite movie of all time. From the opening monologue to the final hat reference it engrosses. The critism of the movie is that the plot is "too complicated" but its not. The dialog is first class, the acting superb and the filming impeccible. A rating of 10 out of 10 from me. No sequels, please.

reviews.review_title: A roller-coaster ride of a 1930's gangster film
reviews.content: This wacky, off-the-wall, deliciously violent gangster film is a remake of Dashiel Hammett's "The Glass Key," first filmed in 1946 with Alan Ladd and Brian Donlevy, with Gabriel Byrne and Albert Finney respectively taking up their roles.  It sets the theme at the beginning with a monologue, a howler of convoluted logic, by racketeer Johnny Caspar (Jon Polito):  if you can't trust the mob to put in a fix, who can you trust?  "It's about ethics," he says to Leo (Albert Finney), the local crime boss, who sits quietly rolling his ice in a glass of scotch. A sullen Gabriel Byrne is Tom Regan, Leo's best friend, confidant, and hatchet man who keeps his cool and whispers sound advice into Leo's ear, advice that Leo too frequently ignores. Poor Mr. Byrne!  I've never seen a protagonist get beaten up so many times - he's even sucker-punched by Leo's girlfriend!  Tom is a black-hearted Irishman in a black hat, and therein lies the imagery of the film: say "heart" with a bit of an Irish brogue and you have "hat." "There's nothing so ridiculous as a man chasing his hat," Tom snarls, and the image of a black hat rolling across the countryside, propelled aimlessly by the wind, recurs frequently.  Tom's a man who goes through life chasing his "heart."  The supporting cast is flawless with Marcia Gay Harden as Verna, Leo's cynical, hard-boiled girlfriend; John Turturro as her brother Bernie, the born loser who sets things in motion by upsetting Johnny's fix, begging for his life on his hands and knees ("Look to your heart, Tom! Look to your heart!" and Steve Buscemi, always a joy to watch, as Mink, a fast-talking two-bit hoodlum. Like all the Coen's films, the characters and situations are surrealistically over the top. The image of Albert Finney, with the map of Ireland all over his face, wearing a yarmulkah at Bernie's orthodox Jewish funeral, is hysterical; likewise the machine-gunning of an innocent bystander whose body is pumped so full of lead during a police raid that he bounces on the sidewalk like a rag doll. If you like the Coen's (which I do) you'll love this film; if you don't, you won't.

There are movies which make you believe there's a god for moviemaking! Miller's Crossing is such a movie! I loved it, I love it and I will always love it! First of all; the Coen bro's are well known for writing excellent stories, Miller's Crossing is a good example Second; the acting in this flick is strong, super strong; John Turturro is excellent, Jon Polito is fantastic and even Steve Buscemi -who is nearly 10 minutes in this movie - shows his talented skills Third; the bro's prove to have an eye for cinema: the visuals, the music, the colors, ... This movie is a masterpiece!

The Coen brothers are known as quality filmmakers and while this movie is one of their best it failed miserably in the box office when it first came out but has now become a cult classic.Tom Reagan (Gabriel Byrne in his best performance) is a consiliere (trusted adviser) who gets into a heap of trouble when his boss Leo (Albert Finney) decides to protect shyster Bernie Bernbaum (John Torturro) from up and coming Italian mob boss Johnny Caspar (Tom Pollito). You see, Leo is in love with Bernie's sister Verna (Marcia Gay Harden) whom Tom happens to be having an affair with.The plot is convoluted and complex as Tom is in a love triangle but also ends up having to take on another love triangle, this time a discreet homosexual one concerning Bernie, a fast-talking bookie named Mink (Steve Buscemi) and Johnny's top enforcer, The Dane (JE Freeman). It's a clash of idealism versus reality as Tom outwits them all, somehow staying above the fray as violence and chaos swirls all around him.Every character is unique in which they have their own quirks and vices. Tom is far from perfect due to his gambling problem and yet he is superior to all the others due to the fact that he is a realist while everybody else is an idealist, meaning they tend to trust their allies and lovers too much while Tom knows the evil that lurks in the hearts of all men (and women). In the end, it is Tom who is the most ruthless of them all because of his cynicism.If you like period drama, complex plot machinations and gangsters, this is a must see film. Don't be afraid if you don't understand it all, it takes several viewings for most people to get it.

I loved it when I saw it in 1990, and repeated viewings have only increased my appreciation for this astonishing film. While "Fargo" may be the Coens' most accessible and darkly funny movie, "Miller's Crossing" is, in my humble view, their very best. To say that MC is a gangster movie is like saying that "Harvey" is a movie about rabbits, however large they may be.Superlative writing, acting and directing. Not one false note. Each character has motivations that are revealed gradually, through their words or through their actions or through their eyes (hidden by hats or not). Gabrielle Byrne has never been better, Marcia Gay Hardin terrific, and Albert Finney? Well, let's just say that he's absolutely convincing whether he's playing a mob boss or a ladies room attendant.Of course, if, like Leo, you "don't like to think," you probably won't care for this movie. But if you enjoy complexity of idea and character motivation, beautiful cinematography, set and costume design, score, and mood, if you liked movies like "Chinatown" or "Donnie Darko" you should check this one out.

reviews.review_title: No, I am not Tom Reagan
reviews.content: It's time to take a balanced view of MILLER'S CROSSING. It is a very good film, with some approaches and scenes touching on genius and pointing ahead to some of the great Coen Brothers work to follow.However, on its own, it is a well-realized film in most regards. Mode, narration, dialog, performances, music, cinematography, and direction are all first rate. MILLER'S CROSSING finds its own "feel" for its topic, for its times, for its genre, and that is a noteworthy achievement for a movie as dark, uncompromising, and uninspiring as it is.The movie seems to say we must live within our destinies--efforts to overcome, or, in Tom Reagan's (Gabriel Byrne's) case, straddle between one destiny or another can be fatal. Tom is razor-smart, smart enough to see several moves ahead in the big game of gangster politics, but also smart enough to see the emptiness of it all. He constantly tries to fight off his own sentimentality, and it gets the best of him, as he needs to be smart or sentimental, not both. And that sentimentality proves fatal for some.What keeps this film short of greatness, in my opinion, is that MILLER'S CROSSING seems to straddle that very line of sentimentality vs. intelligence. In turn, it is a great send-up of gangster pictures, a terrific historical commentary on the ethnic dimension to American gangsters, a wonderful depiction of characters within their era, an existential neo-noir. In the end, however, it seems to fall short of having a lot to say, being content at putting on its show. This makes it, as I said, a very good movie because it has put the show so well.Highly recommended--but beware of the over-praise. It also drags in spots, and at times its over-the-top satire cuts into its effectiveness as drama, or maybe the other way around. In my mind, FARGO remains the most complete Coen film, in a fine body of unusual and idiosyncratic works.

Like others posting here I am a big fan of the Bros. but this one is just a tad dull. The main problem is with the one note quality of the acting. Other than Turturro , and Jon Polito's impression of Michael V . Gazzo from Godfather 2, the acting is flat. Boring. A lot of dead eye staring and tough guy banter. Too much tough guy banter. There is one brilliant scene involving an assasination attempt with Danny Boy playing in the background. Let's just say the Coen's got a lot better after this.

Miller's Crossing Gangster films are violent, take themselves too seriously, and are slow (well, most). Luckily, Miller's Crossing only takes one of these characteristics, and is, along with some others, considered mob masterpieces. Many will disagree with me, but I found this to be a more entertaining and well-made film than The Godfather and Bonnie and Clyde, but not as good as Goodfellas or The Public Enemy. It has situations that are uncomfortable, suspenseful, and grim, and turns them into black comedy hilarity. This film not only succeeds on the gangster picture level, but on a number of other levels: black comedy, suspense, and a dab of film noir that it seems the makers enjoyed referencing to. Not only that, but it is brilliantly written. This has perhaps one of the most clever screenplays I've ever encountered, with dialogue and situations. The Coens make this film hilarious, bleak, and very violent all at the same time as we try to decide just who we are rooting for and, every once in awhile, what exactly is going on during this complex black comedy. For intelligent viewers, you got one for the brain here. The intellectual film buff should view this film immediately as it is lots of fun and likes to trick it's characters and sometimes the viewer into thinking things that are not. Seeing what our anti-hero will do next is quite worthy of the money spent at Blockbuster. I highly recommend the film. 3.5 stars out of four. Written by Joel and Ethan Coen. Directed by Ethan Coen. Cast: Gabriel Byrne, John Turturro, Albert Finney and Jon Polito. 1990. Rated R for language and violence.

reviews.review_title: The best postmodern gangster film every made, rivaling even The Godfather in cinematic perfection.
reviews.content: The deep-focus in almost every scene combined with the consistently Rembrandt-like cinematography, with faces lit or half-lit against a dark background, make for a compelling visually satisfying aesthetics in this film. Yes, there is blood galore, but never is it gratuitous. Killing is not pretty. Guns have consequences. The dancing figure of a mobster being riddled by machine gun fire makes death a reality, not a glamorous event. The Coen Brothers reference the 1930's gangster films, especially Public Enemy and White Heat, as well as The Godfather. Their own twist is the element of a homosexual love triangle, the irony being that the most brutal and conscienceless mobsters are not heterosexual macho men. The issue of having a heart is raised again and again through the film, and the consequences of having one in such a brutal world provides another irony in this often sentimental, but honest look at man's greed, at man's essential lust for power. Only Verna has a heart and seems capable of love. Tom, too, has a heart, but his love for Verna can easily be dismissed as lust. However, he and Verna both have unswerving loyalty, loyalty that is assuredly misplaced, but loyalty nonetheless. The theme of family which is part of the gangster genre also has a postmodern twist here. There is the ludicrous family of Johnny Caspar, the sibling connection between Verna and Bernie, and the father-son relationship between Leo and Tom. This last verges on the homoerotic in the last scene. The haunting musical score is reminiscent of old movies, with Tom's theme, a melody played at the beginning, the end, and points between when Tom is on screen and in trouble. One is reminded of Tara's theme in Gone with the Wind. The dialogue is fast paced, so much so that even my students, normally highly acute when it comes to movies, found it difficult to follow on the first viewing. Actually, the subtlety of expression adds to this difficulty. Listen, for instance, to the clues to the fact that there is a gay love triangle. If you don't catch them, the plot makes little sense.
