The homosexuality is never overtly stated, nor are the comments about the gay relationship ever highlighted in any way. There is no use of words like "faggot" to finger the gay characters, but it is clear who they are if you're listening. This is a movie that has to be seen more than once. It itself, so referential to older gangster movies, has been referenced by more recent ones like Road to Perdition. To date, I think it is the best of Coen Brothers' movies and I like almost all of the others.

`Miller's Crossing' was an odd movie.  I keep wondering when it was going to start.  You get pulled into the story gradually and before you know it it's over.  It is entertaining and nicely filmed.   Albert Finney, John Tutturro and Jon Polito were good.  Gabriel Byrne was morose and wasn't all that likeable in his role.  There weren't many likeable characters in the movie but at least they seemed to be open about who they were.  Byrne's character lied and cheated everyone in the movie.  It was a strange movie but engaging.  Similar to `Road to Perdition' and easily superior.

reviews.review_title: No clue why this has such a high user rating.
reviews.content: This movie was slightly better than average. Not bad but not really that good. I can't believe it has a rating of 8 or greater. I could see justification for that high of a rating if the ending was a lot better, and I mean a lot better. As far as closure, which is necessary for any good story, there is none. I was left with no idea of who Tom was and why he did everything he did. Didn't even know whether he had a goal from the beginning at all. In fact this whole fact makes this movie horrible. The only reason why I gave it a 6 was because it could have been a good movie if they had just had a real ending. Tom had absolutely no personality that one could connect to in a certain way. He protects this mob boss and then he decieves him to protect another for no given reason at all. It just doesn't make sense whatsoever. The only reason I watched this movie is because of the high user rating of it. Just goes to show you how peoples taste differ I guess, except for the fact that there is no discernible point to this movie at all, and I don't know one of my friends who would like this movie. I never have commented on a movie on this site but I couldn't let this go. Thanks.

A complex tale which ultimately feels largely unsatisfying all told. It is the most sombre and despite the complex plot, straight forward of the Coens' films.I enjoyed the smart witty dialogue delivered expertly by Jon Polito particularly but the rest of the cast deliver fine performances too i think it felt all too contrived and a bit too smart for its own good at times and also a bit cheesy with the score.This one for me is tier 2 Coen Bros.

This is a modern gangster film noir. It plays with the stereotypes known from the early gangster films and film noirs from the 40ies. In a more modern way there is a lot of screen violence, film blood is used very excessively. The violence in this film, however, is a very artificial one. It doesn't hurt the viewer, but it doesn't have to, because film noir was never a genre of forced realism. It's much more a genre that examines the "dark side" of humans, the way he treats his unmoral wishes and drives. The Coen Brothers add to this mix a comic-y approach to this story, which isn't quite my taste, although they build up some great moments that remain. But in some moments of this movie, I asked myself what is this particular scene contributing to the movie (or is this just an exercise in style?). Gabriel Byrne plays very well in the lead, and also his co-stars Marcia Gay Harden, Jon Polito and Albert Finney are convincing in their parts.

reviews.review_title: The best mobster movie ever made
reviews.content: This movie succeeds in so many ways; there's no way I can get into it all here.  One particularly strong point is the way that the seedy doings of gangsters is depicted with the Coen Bros' absurdist touch.  Another is the way that the whole story ties together; there isn't one plot hole that I can think of, the Coens just cover all their bases really well.  This movie is really *written*, if you know what I mean.  I've seen Goodfellas, The Godfather, Scarface, etc. and I say this movie beats them all simply because it provides an element that all those other films lack.  I cannot extol the Coen Bros enough, this is one of their very best.

Coen at it's best in a well staged gangster saga of friendship, betrayal, well designed intrigues in a perfect plot, playing out perfectly by a cat lead by Albert Finney, Gabriel Byrne, John Turturro and Marcia Gay Hayden, however cast over by certain blasts of brutality. Not suitable for younger people in any case, as it also requires a lot of focus to follow all the well designed threads of the master plot. In my view, much better as "Once Upon a Time", so never so high rated. Watch it, if you like this type of movie, you won't regret it.

Spoiler alert: This synopsis may contain information that could be considered spoilers to some readers.Miller's Crossing is one of my favorite Coen brothers movies. It helped a lot, of course, that all of the actors were well cast. Jon Polito as Caspar was his usual superb self, somehow managing to simultaneously keep his character both likable and despicable. Gabriel Byrne as Tom was a great punching bag who somehow emerged from every beating just as handsome as he was before it started. J.E. Freeman was excellent as Caspar's psychopathic gay hit-man. John Turturro as Bernie Bernbaum, the apparently gay brother of Verna, added an ongoing menace to the film. Marcia Gay Harden was wonderful as Verna and looked perfect in the role.Since I don't think I can improve on previous positive reviews, I would prefer to address the gay innuendo that is present throughout the movie but is frequently overlooked. It is certainly not the central focus of the story which is probably why so few viewers pick up on it (and even as a gay viewer, I have to include myself among them). Once all the clues are pointed out, you wonder how you could possibly not have seen them.First of all, we can be sure that at least three of the characters are gay: Psycho hit-man Eddie Dane and his lover, Mink. Also there is Bernie Bernbaum who is having a secret and potentially dangerous affair with Mink, largely for the purpose of gaining information. Below are some of the clues, not necessarily in order:Clue one: The movie opens with Caspar and Eddie Dane in Leo's office. Caspar is trying to get Leo to allow him to put a hit on some guy named Bernie whom he suspects of hurting his fixed bets by selling information. Bernie, however, is the brother of Leo's girlfriend, Verna, so Leo is very reluctant. Leo suggests that maybe Eddie's friend Mink is responsible for the betrayal. Eddie quickly comes to Mink's defense and Caspar backs him up by saying that Mink is Eddie's "boy". In another moment during that scene, Eddie and Tom exchange knowing glances that suggest more than mutual disdain or admiration. My take on that moment is that Eddie is sadistically attracted to Tom and that is exactly how Tom sees it. I don't think the attraction is mutual.Clue Two: In the scene where Tom is at the club talking to Mink. The conversation more than suggests that Eddie and Mink are lovers and that Mink is having an affair with Bernie behind Eddie's back. Tom tells Mink that it wouldn't be good if Eddie were to find out that Mink has another "amigo" because he doesn't take Eddie for the understanding type. Mink quickly becomes very concerned that Tom might squeal on him.Clue Three: Tom is talking to Caspar, trying to convince him that Eddie is a betrayer. During that scene, Caspar again says that Mink is Eddie's boy. He even adds that he, himself, doesn't go that way. Tom, referring to Eddie and Mink, says something to the effect, "There's always that wild card (a slight pause, he raises his eyebrows) where love is involved."Clue Four: After Tom pushes his way into the ladies' powder room to talk to Verna, she tells him how her brother is misunderstood just because he's "different". Clue Five: There is also the scene in Tom's apartment where Bernie says that his own sister tried to seduce him and the suggestion is that she was trying to make him heterosexual. I know that some people see homoeroticism between Leo and Tom but I don't see anything erotic about their relationship. I think they love each other and are deeply devoted to each other but that's as far as it goes.As a bit of trivia, in real life Joe Polito who plays Caspar, and J.E. Freeman who plays Eddie Dane, really are openly gay.

Superb venture by the Coen brothers into the gangster genre suffers because of comparisons to "Goodfellas" and "The Godfather".  No, it's not as good as those, and it does fall into some of the genre's cliches, but the storytelling is so good it's easy to ignore what flaws it may have.  The plot concerns a mob boss's right hand man (Gabriel Byrne), and the complicated events that follow after his boss (Albert Finney) refuses to give up protection to a bookie. (John Turturro)  The excellent script is performed well by the entire cast, but Byrne and Turturro in particular, top off with some incredibly beautiful cinematography.

Very noire. Also more theatrical then "realistic." Not really a gangster movie. It's more like a Shakespeareian thing. But it uses a gangster setting. And plenty of over the top action sequences, still, it's not really about the gangster stuff, it's about the story and characters and mainly the lead characters journey. I personally thought it was a weird film at first, kind of strange film. The plot a little too hard to follow and you get thrown right into it. And a little hard to catch up on all the dialgue and remember who is who. But when I got into it, it's was very impactful movie, very well made. I guess you have to expect some strangeness when it's a Coen movie. It also has that very dark and not so obvious humor, when you're not really sure if it's suppose to be funny, that the Coen brothers are masters of.It's also very well shot and very well acted by all actors involved. I liked how strong and independent the leading lady was, Marcia Gay Harden did that very well. I also thought John Turturro was really good. And off course Albert Finney was good too. I also have to mention this film uses music very sparingly, but the score that is there fits very well and is dramatic and beautiful.My biggest complaints about the movie is that it gets a little slow and boring, it kind of have this dimmerd down depressing tone, but you still have to stay focused or you won't get a thing of what's going on. I guess that it's style, so it might work also, if that's what you like. But if you're like me, it was kind of hard to get into and it took me probably 30 min or more until I was invested in the story enough to care or enjoy myself, almost turned it off actually thinking about watching something more fun and entertaining instead. But as I said, I really did come to like it. Also, I didn't really get who the leading man was suppose to be, is he a smuck that just gets lucky sometimes or is he a complete badass? Well, might give it a second viewing to make up my mind about that and see what else I missed also.I wouldn't necessarily recommend this movie to someone that wants to see a gangster movie. Someone that are up for something a bit different and a smart convoluted story though. Sure. This might just be the ticket. But you are warned. I really don't think this movie is for everyones liking.

reviews.review_title: Lack of energy and clearly overrated
reviews.content: During the prohibition era, Tom (Gabriel Byrne) is the closest and loyal Lieutenant of Leo, a crime boss (Albert Finney). Rivalry and war between Leo and Johnny Caspar, another crime boss, starts when Leo refuses to kill Bernie, a small time crook (John Turturro). Leo could not kill Bernie because he has an affair with Verna (Marcia Gay Harden ) who has also an affair with Tom. When Tom says that to Leo, Leo ends violently their collaboration and Tom decides to work for Caspar. Things get complicated when Caspar orders Tom to kill Bernie. Does Tom have a heart not to execute this order?From the beginning to the end, this movie is lacking energy in the direction. As it is usually the case in movies by the Coen Brothers, humor is present by appears only in small and secondary scenes. These moments of comedy seems to come at some points where the directors were probably bored by what they were showing. This story of loyalty and betrayal (between Tom and Leo and Tom and Verna) doesn't go straight to our hearts because we have no sympathy for the characters. Gabriel Byrne with his beaten-dog eyes is good but his performance has nothing exciting. Only Albert Finney and John Turturro are above the rest of the cast. This movie was inspired by the `Glass Key', an excellent movie by Stuart Heisler with Alan Ladd and Veronica Lake (and also an adaptation of a novel by Dashiell Hammett). Some scenes are similar in both movies, but overall, the story and the ending are different. I was clearly disappointed by this one. The Coen Brothers should not attempt to do dramas but keep up the good work with comedies. Clearly overrated 7/10.

I got to tell you, when I saw this film last week. I thought it was a astonishing movie. I was left speechless. Miller's Crossing was one in a few Coen Brothers films that I haven't seen. Now I need to see tow more of their films: The Hudsucker Proxy and Blood Simple. When I first heard of this film and around the time I have heard of The Coen Brothers, I had no idea this film was directed by them. I thought it was directed by Martin Scorsese. Anyway, this is arguably the best film by the Coen Brothers. I mean, it was a good movie. This is my first time seeing this film so I need to see it again sometime. I hope someday it will be released on DVD. Because I have a Surround Sound so when the action sequences are on, the box will tremble. Excellent gangster movie. I recommend it.10 out of 10

reviews.review_title: Visually stunning, the best dialogue ever, great actors, yet it has a very confusing plot and resolution
reviews.content: As a big Coen brothers fan, I jumped at the chance when I noticed this one at the video store.  What I loved the most were the larger than life characters (obviously parodies from the old gangster movies with James Cagney) the beautiful cinematography, the Coen's artistic sense of direction (one in particular was the long shot of Albert Finney's character turning his back to Tom, right before he beats the tar out of him), the over the top, campy violence, and of course, most importantly, the dialogue.  Never have I ever heard such impressive dialogue...sorry Kevin Smith, though some of your films are funny (like Mallrats), they can't hold a candle to this one.  This one is so intelligent it is a pleasure to watch.  Gabriel Byrne was incredible in the role of the 'heartless' crook, Tom, who plays a deadly game of switching sides between two rival gangs.  Always a pleasure to watch, and without a doubt, his best performance, ever.  I must say that J.E. Freeman's 'The Dane' character was just too cool.  He was so brooding, so calm and precise, yet, you could feel his thirst for blood just by the look in his eyes.  Definitely a memorable character.  I was pleased to see John Turturro and Steve Buscemi turning in yet two more good performances for the Coens.  All in all, every actor was excellent, and the film was very entertaining.My only complaint is the same as many others who have reviewed this film on this site.  That feeling of 'huh?' at the end, and often, during the film was honestly a turn off.  I know the Coens always have a message about the human condition or human psyche in their films, but save for the fact that Tom is obviously trying to find his heart throughout the film, it is never quite clear, nor is the resolution.  To tell you the truth, I don't even know why he told his boss of the affair he was having with his girlfriend (which starts the whole crossing/double crossing/Miller's Crossing acts), perhaps futility?  I definitely need to see this one again, which I definitely plan to.  Unfortunately, though, the wonderful film Memento, though it grips you just like this one does, Memento at least gave you a hint that there was something deeper to things, and after about three viewings, you suddenly get it and it makes the movie ten times better.  I did not get this feeling with Miller's Crossing, primarily b\c I saw very little of the vulnerability of the main character.  Every now and then, his girl would mention how cold his heart is, but other than that, you really don't see him struggling, nor reach an epiphany at any point.  The only part that gives any indication of a dawning moment of comprehension, or clarity is the final scene, which to me it totally ambiguous...but perhaps that was the intention.  If so, kudos for making the audience think, but at the same time, it feels a tad bit like a cop out.  Is he running away from his life and now starting over again?  Did he feel that he was incapable of love at the end and decided to keep his loyalties, but not his love?  I just don't have the answers, but hopefully I will after rewatching it again, soon. Another minor gripe was how they kept referring to all of these other characters, some of whom we hardly see...with the local color from Irish, Italians and Jews, the accents alone, in addition to the countless characters mentioned can cause a headache, and good use of the rewind button.  But despite these complaints, I can't help but feel like this was a good movie, and for me to say that, that is definitely a rarity, indeed.Anyway, on a first viewing, I give it a 7.5, b\c it is very entertaining to watch.  Because of the incredibly intelligent dialogue that comes at you a mile a minute and had me in stiches or sitting in awe more times than I could count, I give it a strong 8.  For anything else, see this as a somewhat 'satire' of gangster films, while still being a good one...yet, like all of the Coen films, don't take the situations seriously or it will ruin the experience for you.  8/10 stars...That's my story and I'm sticking to it.

reviews.review_title: Dashiell Hammett's Glass Key brought successfully to film. - 8 of 10
reviews.content: The Coen brothers kept true to Hammett's use of the dialogue of the day and the plot spins are mostly accurate.  Byrne does great work as the punching bag.  I had a harder time with Finney fitting into his role, but he does well and is a great actor.  How his Tommy gun has 150+ bullet's in it, is amazing to me, but then I've seen six-shooters have 15 or 20 rounds, too. More Buscemi would've been good, since he fits the atmosphere of the film perfectly and Tuturro is in his element, too.  All in all, a very well made film, but don't give the Coen brothers all the credit, Dashiell Hammett's Glass Key was the impetus of this film. Read The Glass Key and Red Harvest for some great gangster action.  -  8 of 10

Despite its overtones from "The Glass Key," this movie does a tremendous job of hooking you into the premise very quickly.There's an immediate conflict for the protagonist here, and like Blood Simple, the Coen's earlier films seemed to give more care to the plot as it winds up tightly. Of course, the role of Johnny Caspar is delicious and Polito knocks it out of the part in ways few actors could, and coupled with the savvy of Finney's mob boss, you quickly and clearly gain the gist of the dilemma that Tom faces, and immediately snuggle in for the rest of the movie. Too bad the Brothers abandoned their faith in plot and headed towards a wild disregard for any coherence after "Fargo." I miss the sense of fate that plays a part in their best movies, stories that seem like they are headed towards a serious and inevitable conclusion. The clumsy ones all feel like they lost their willingness to see the narrative through to its natural end.

No question, this film feels contrived - too contrived, actually. More than one viewer has ended up like Verna. " I don't understand. I don't care!"But if you like puzzles - the more intricate, the better - this is for you. It's rich in manipulations, betrayals, doublings and triangles.Some viewers may sense a void at the heart of the film. The characters, with their dry, hard-surfaced performances, give very little away. Where is the emotion powering the whole complex machination? The name for it, in Leo's words, is 'joy de veever," and Verna, the 'angel,' embodies it.The story, unfolding in scenes that play almost like tableaux, introduces its themes at once. For starters, there's the lighting: bright for public spaces, dim for private. Then there's the color scheme: green for Tom and 'friendship', red for Leo and passion,The driver of the plot is, as Casper declares right at the beginning, ethics, i.e., moral choice, right and wrong. Accordingly, Leo asks Tom 'which side' he's on today. That is also why there are so many scene doublings as the choice is repeated in a slight twist.The characters represent at least four standards of morality. 1) Beasts, like Mink, who have no sense of right and wrong, merely acting on their drives, creating anarchy, the jungle. 2) Caspar, who uses the 'fear of god,' i.e., threats of violence or death, to establish order. 3) Leo, the Lionheart, who helps friends and hurts enemies. 4) Tom, who icily judges gains and losses. Tom - and only Tom - is addressed, 'Jesus, Tom,' or 'Christ, Tom,' and he can raise the dead.'God invented cards,' declares Tom, and he seems to believe choice is limited: you have to play the cards you're dealt; but you have a moral choice about how you play them.Money, as often in Coen Brothers movies, corrupts relationships. That's why Tom rejects Leo's offer to square his accounts with his bookie.Maybe in the end the key to the secret motive is to be found in the dreamlike sequence of the wind-blown hat (like so many scenes, doubled later in the film). Oddly, the dream hat is not Tom's. Tom wears a gray-brown fedora. The dream hat is black. Who wears a black fedora? The Dane? Leo? My interpretation is that the first part, with the green title cards set against a cathedral of green trees and accompanied by intensely emotional music (I leave it to the viewer to put a name to the emotion.), represents Tom's 'friendship' with Leo. The second part, with the red (Leo) title card "miller's crossing' leading to the hat sequence, represents Tom's apprehension that the relationship is threatened..There follows a brief black-out, and Tom is shown waking from his dream. Returning to a world of lies and manipulation, he asks, "Who're you gonna believe?"
I have no idea how this film got so many "10's". This movie was not enjoyable, perhaps, I am not intellectual enough because I expect to be entertained, This was not entertaining.

I think you need to be a film buff who loves film history to enjoy this film, otherwise you'll get bored like I did. Film plods along never quite reaching any sort of satisfying climax or resolution. Theres an odd assembly of equally odd caricatures but I didn't really care about any of them at the end of the day. I mean...it's a pretty film, set design wise and all, and the actors do well with their roles but after the novelty of that wears off I was really just waiting for the film to end. I can't even spoil this plot because I didn't feel like there is much to spoil. It's not for us unwashed philistines, apparently, and thats fine. But thats why for me its 4/10.

reviews.review_title: Maybe I omitted a few things
reviews.content: In a previous review I said that Miller's Crossing had few merits. I should maybe ad one of the merits.(SPOILERS START HERE)This movie plays around with the idea of loyalty. And the Coen Brothers play around with a lot of irony, as they usually do in their movies. In the movie we see Tom (Garbriel Byrne) switch sides to the other mob in town, but secretly he is still loyal to his old boss Leo (Finney), even though Leo doesn't know it. His new boss (Polito) thinks he's loyal to him, but Dane, Polito's 2nd in command, sees through Tom. Yet Dane in the end gets killed by his boss for something he did not do, and then get betrayed by Tom anyway.Another one is Finney's relationship with Verna. He would never cheat on her but she's cheating on Tom. Also Tom is loyal to his friend Bernie and, ironically, Bernie ends up being disloyal to his friends, especially Tom.(SPOILER ENDS HERE)It also shows that trust (or distrust) should be well founded and not taken on what people say because trust, as truth and loyalty, depends on how it is perceived by an individual.Then there was the "Danny Boy" sequence.Other than this, Miller's Crossing was disappointing.

The Coen brothers just can't live up to my post-Fargo expectations. In one way or the other they just seem to dissapoint me. In Hudsucker Proxy the ending was just too abstract (although I do respect it), O brother where art thou had a lot of funny scenes but just does not hold together in a movie (the sham spirituality doesn't help). The Man who Wasn't there, although good, is slow and a bit cold around the heart and the Big Lebowski was just plain nasty. All of the above average or just slightly above average.Miller's Crossing, although rather good, is still just slightly above average. It has good acting, good script, etc. But, for some reason, the first 20 minutes are boring. It lags a lot during, and can be a bit too slow. And it, yet again, it's cold around the heart. It lacks a sense of human warmth (that Fargo had, although not at first glance).It dissapointed like most of the Coen brother's film, and, although I know you should view each movie on it's own merits, I hate to say that Miller's Crossing has very few.

Not to mention "schmatte." Considering the fact that as writer the Coens are famous for having every word of dialogue set in stone before the shooting begins, maybe the system is no longer working. A beautifully filmed tribute to the film noir with an intricate enough plot to maintain our interest, the only drawback is with the dialogue. Still it is well above the average Hollywood film even if it does not reach "The Big Lebowski"/ "Raising Arizona" level.

This is without a doubt the best Hammett I've seen in theaters. "The Glass Key" brought to life. Byrne and Finney are excellent, while Turturro is positively slimy. Great visuals and a moody, ambivalent script. All other gangster flicks wish they could serve up such a stew. Violence never looked so good.

This is a magnificent moody, atmospheric movie, alwaysmaintaining a tension that keeps us glued to the screen. It showsboth the fragility and vulnerability of Tom as well as a sense ofinvincibility. Coen Brother's movies are typically full of ironies andapparent contradictions in the human condition; they certainlyunderstand human nature, as we often drift between these statesof being and feeling. Because they understand and portray humannature so well, their films will remain timeless, as Shakespearehas.  Has Tom got a heart? The answer becomes clear, and hismotives become clear in the very last shot of him pulling his hatdown and staring down the track in the forest. Tom survives byusing his brain and tact; some live by instinct, such as Verna, most rely on guns and violence, or a perceived code of underworldethics, or talking alot  ( Bernie )... all of which Tom is very reluctantto use. His mind is his weapon. He also has maintained contactsin high places. He doesn't say too much or perform heroics; heknows how to survive in this dog eat dog world. The soundtracksuperbly complements the mood, with its Irish melancholy. Theperformances are immaculate. The plot is rich, and as complicated as allegiances and trust. Tom is very believable andhuman, such as when we see him vomiting. We all have a heart,emotions, and conscience; Tom supresses these elements as heknows they will be weaknesses in this dangerous world. Do wesupress ours?

This movie was engaging, complicated and intricate, and well thought out and put together. I still don't think I'd put it on the top 250 list, but I'd definitely give it a 7/10.My one qualm in this was realism. It was very realistic in many senses, and the characters were realistically portrayed, but it's the minor details that bugged me while I watched. My best example for this is Tom's apparent invincibility. It seemed like every time he stepped out of a doorway, phone booth, room, building, car, etc etc etc, he was getting punched in the face, and then kicked in the head, and then punched and slapped around and just generally having the crap kicked out of him. Repeatedly. Okay, I can believe that someone in his line of work would get beat up sometimes, especially if he's not a big guy. But you *have* to show some bruises if you get beat up that badly. The best we got was some short-lived blood, and once a small split in his lip (which vanishes very quickly). In general, two seconds after the baddies finish knocking him around he's back on his feet and totally fine, not even disheveled.The other problem I had was more with me than with the movie, but when someone is standing right next to you or in front of you or over you with a gun three inches from your body *telling* you that you're about to die, the least you can do is grab the gun and hit the guy a few times and see if he drops the gun. Everyone in this movie seemed too afraid of the all-powerful handgun held half an arm's-length away, and unwilling to even try to escape its narrow range of effectiveness. It could be that I'm too well trained and am overanalyzing the potential combat situations which were to further the plot and not act as plot themselves, and it's true that this isn't a Jet Li action thriller, but the least they could do would be to take away the possibility of stopping the gun-weilder by having them step back one pace.In all I enjoyed the film and marveled at its intricate construction and effective visual style, and everyone delivered excellent performances. My qualms with it are primarily superficial, so although this movie in my opinion isn't top 250 material it is still very good.

SPOILERS ALL OVER ITAgain I'm surprised by the unbelievable talent of the Coen Bros for creating their own, personal, unique atmospheres for each one of their films and by their awesome creativity. And I also love, as a fan of classic cinema and a constant reader, their constant references and winks to books and films.This one features the enormous Gabriel Byrne playing the part of a cold-hearted assistant for a gangster who surprisingly has never killed anybody and has a recurrent dream in wich he's standing in the middle of the Miller's Crossing forest and his hat is taken away by the wind to never come back. The funny part of it is that during the whole movie this stands as a metaphor, for the hat is constantly falling from his head but he always manages to get it back when it seems it's too late. Finally, is really too late because he does murder someone (and for no reason at all). But in the end he goes to the guy's funeral in Miller's Crossing and the hat stays in his head all the time. Again we find a completely meaningless subject paid too much atention.There's also a lot of laughing-out-loud parts, specially the ones featuring Jon Polito and constant witty remarks, just like on the classic film-noir novels by Dasshiell Hammett and Raymond Chandler.The acting is another chapter entirely. Gabriel Byrne's superb in his role, but the supportings really deserve the palm. John Turturro, Jon Polito, Albert Finney, Garcia May Harden and a short but well-played Steve Buscemi character.However, I still prefer the Coen's most recent works (and I'm talking about "Oh Brother", "The man who wasn't there" and specially "The big Lebowski" here). But this one's worth more than a view.SAY NO MORE

Joel & Ethan Coen's extraordinary gangster epic is a totally engrossing cinematic experience. It concerns a black-hearted mobster named Tom Reagan, played sensationally by Gabriel Byre in performance of great subtlety, he has his own personal code of ethics known only to himself. Tom is the right-man to a powerful Irish Mob kingpin and political boss named Leo O' Bannon, magnificently played to the hilt by the late great British actor Albert Finney in an absolutely phenomenal scene-stealing performance. Tom's secret is the sexual relationship with Leo's gal pal, Verna Bernbaum played wonderfully played by Marcia Gay Harden in her screen debut. It will test his loyalty to Leo, who he has a major falling out with over Verna, then forges a shaky alliance with Leo's chief rivals, a psychotic Italian mobster named Johnny Casper, played impressively by the Jon Polito, and his sadistic lieutenant Eddie Dane, memorably played by the J. E. Freeman, who are both threatening Leo's racket. Impeccable supporting performances from Danny Aiello III, Joey Ancona, Michael Badalucco, Steve Buscemi, Kevin Dearie, and Esteban Fernandez, with special kudos to John Turturro who delivers a noteworthy performance as Verna's slimy gay brother Bernie Bernbaum. There is a tour-de-force unforgettable sequence of sheer filmmaking brilliance when two Tommy gun armed assassins try to murder Leo in his own home, it is one of the finest gun shootout action scenes that I have ever seen, where Finney's tough kingpin character shows why he is still number one. The period recreation is flawless and the screenplay by the Coen bros is brilliant. Impressive cinematography by Barry Sonnenfeld, and a magnificent production design by Dennis Gassner. Carter Burwell's exquisite musical score is exceptional. A must see!
Apparently one of their best. If so don't waste your time with any of their movies. Got absolutely nothing on a Godfather or Goodfellas. Fell very flat and I was bored throughout the whole thing.

reviews.review_title: One of the greatest of all American movies
reviews.content: It's absurd that this film is not far up on the IMDb list of the top 250. It's virtually perfect, from Carter Burwell's superb music on. Not just a profound version of the gangster film, but also one of the Coen Bros.' best cinematic meditations on their great, central theme of human stupidity and cluelessness. Having dealt with dumb hicks in Texas and Arizona, as well as a fool Jew in Barton Fink, the Coens turn their satirical laser on the Irish (and, to a lesser extent, the Jews) in Miller's Crossing, to even better, more complex effect. Acting doesn't get better than Gabriel Byrne, Albert Finney, John Turturro, Marcia Gay Harden, and the whole superb cast. Brilliant, hilariously dark script. Amazing cinematography. Great direction, sets, costumes, editing. It doesn't get better than this in American film.

reviews.review_title: A Handsome Film About Men In Hats
reviews.content: Most of the Coen Brothers' films could be best described as homages to films from different eras or genres they personally love and 'Miller's Crossing' best exemplifies this.Unlike most typical homage films, the Coen Brothers do not simply imitate the style of different genres but instead use genre films to create an experience with their own unique screenwriting and cinematic style.Obviously, this film is firmly placed in the gangster genre. It contains all the usual plot devices a typical gangster film has like gang rivalry, excessive violence, brutal hit-men, double crossing, and a smart-mouthed hard-boiled protagonist. Unlike other gangster films, the Coen Brothers infuse this film with their hallmark surrealism and dark comedy.Many critics have speculated on the meaning of the opening scene with a hat blowing in the wind and when asked about it, the Coen Brothers simply replied that sometimes a hat blowing in the wind is simply a hat blowing in the wind. When discussing how to photograph the film, the Coen Brothers told cinematographer, Barry Sonnenfeld that visually speaking, they wanted it to be a handsome movie about men in hats. Indeed, Tom's hat could be considered the central character of the film.The only drawback to the film is the difficulty of following the complex story; much of that has to do with the use of vernacular specific to the era it takes place in. Yet, even though the story can be difficult to follow, this is ultimately a good thing because it gives you a reason to watch this brilliant work of cinema again.

Although this film is obviouly well written, directed and acted it leaves me with an empty feeling every time I watch it. Possibly because there's no real way to relate to the characters. Tom is simply a fast talking yet clever thug. The problem, though, is that he's simply a satire on past 30's and 40's crime characters. Perhaps he's too clever and too fast talking. He steps over the bounds of suspension of disbelief. I would recommend Miller's Crossing to friends because so many people tend to like it but it's not one for me.

The first time I saw this "gangster" movie, I was amused by the argot strewn dialogue .  Phrases like "What's the rumpus?" and "Always with the high hat" aren't heard in too many crime films, where verisimilitude is considered necessary for a "realistic" depiction of criminal enterprise.  The setting seems to be some mythical second tier city with little connection to a larger crime syndicate, and the period seems to be perhaps the twenties, with some of the cops still wearing handlebar moustaches.   If you've read anything about the Coen Bros., you know they grew up as film junkies, enamored of Hercules movies and Don Siegel style '50s B flicks.  "Miller's Crossing" is a thesis movie, a comment on the remote, mythical world of film, with little regard for any kind of faithful depiction of American crime.  In this regard, it has a lot in common with the works of Sergio Leone. The "Danny Boy" sequence is one of the few examples in recent memory of a scene in a movie that clobbers you with its greatness before you are told by some film critic that it is a valid "great scene."

First i thought it is gonna be an old boring movie, but i was very surprise and amaze by this movie after all it's Joel Coen, Ethan Coen direction. movie is just gr8 the twist and turns keeps the movie very interesting, the was Tom plays with the mafia bosses. I think the perfect villain is Bernie Bernbaum (John Turturro) the whole story revolves around him. Tom first wants him separated from Eddie Dane so he can get Verna but then circumstances changed, Tom teamed up with other mafia boss Johnny Caspar but it was just Deception. Tom plays both Bosses but he likes Eddie more, all he cares about was Verna. The story line is just gr8 and very strong, i like the way Tom manipulates both bosses all credits goes to story and direction.

reviews.review_title: It's Gabriel Byrne. It's Gabriel Byrne in a fedora.
reviews.content: So, what's the rumpus? While overall not a bad movie, it was missing something. It did have Gabriel Byrne in one of his usual strong roles, however, so that helped. If you like crime dramas you will like it. There's a good amount of deception, deceit, and mind games. And if you like seeing John Turturro whimper in fear and seeing Gabriel Byrne be beaten to a bloody pulp every ten minutes or so, this is definitely your movie.

reviews.review_title: I love this film. I want to marry it!
reviews.content: Supremely witty, immensely beautiful, astonishingly clever, brutally violent and quite frankly, inspiring, this is by far the Coen brothers best movie. Brilliant performances by all, but particularly Jon Polito and J.E. Freeman - this is a far better gangster movie than your bog standard Italian Mob flick. And its been said before, but hey, who cares, the Danny Boy scene is genius. The best film that most people haven't heard of ever.

reviews.review_title: Lots of crossing!! Lots of people will lost their way to understand this movie
reviews.content: Woww!! I mean, heck! Joel Coen completely nailed it. Lots of twists and lots of faces. Watch the movie, listen to the words more carefully.

reviews.review_title: Good movie, very fast moving plot
reviews.content: 1. Good movie with a very fast moving plot so there was never a dull moment.2. You will always be on your toes because to get most out of the movie you will have to try to understand who is plotting/strategizing what.3. Acting by all characters was very smooth.

Miller's Crossing is a movie that I first viewed early in High School.  At the time, I was an incompetent movie-watcher.  I didn't pay much attention to the film and, as a result didn't "get" much of it.  When I watched it again, years later, the movie really seemed to come to life.  Even though I've now watched this film well over a dozen times, I still catch new details with each additional viewing.  For instance, how many people have noticed the creaking trees from Miller's Crossing in the last scene with Tom and Bernie outside of Tom's apartment?  At first I simply thought it was the floorboards creaking.  If you watch and listen carefully, you'll notice that it's not in sync with Tom or Bernie walking -- or even moving.  How many people have noticed the silver ring on Tom's right hand?  It's an Irish wedding band, turned to signify that his heart belongs to another.  To whom does it belong?  Verna?  Leo?Anyway, as almost everyone here has said, this is a great film with a lot of great performances and cameos.  I know I'll never forget such memorable characters as Tom, Bernie, Verna, Leo, The Dane, Jonny, Tic-Tac, Frankie, Terry, Mink, Drop Johnson, and Tad.

reviews.review_title: The best film the Coens have done.
reviews.content: Now, here's something that never made any sense: How come Fargo got all the accolades & this film was largely ignored? In terms of dialogue, scriptwriting, and character development this film is far & beyond Fargo. Here it's more important to LISTEN.Now, when the hell will it be released on DVD?? If there was ever a film that's screaming out to be put on disc this is it!

This is the third film from master filmmakers Joel and Eathen Coen is a masterpiece of the gangster genre> Gabriel Byrne (The Usual Suspects) is awesome as gangster. this character is a character sees all the angles. The Coen's group of actors in this film where JOHN TURTURRO Joe Polito, Macdormand (a little scene) Sam Rami, and little part by my favorite actor Steve Buscemi.Working for a crime boss and trying to make piece is hard play but Tommy makes it work. Like any other good gangster film you have to watch the whole way through till the end especially Gabreil's trials and tribulations The Coen brothers are the best film making team and this is one of the examples why

I believe this to be the Coen brother's best movie, and it's my favorite movie of all time. Usually I don't like gangster movies, but this seems to reach deeper levels by having an interesting plot and good characterizations from all involved. Marcia Gay Harden is especially good, as are Albert Finney and Gabriel Byrne, but all are effective, even Steve Bushemi in only one scene.The movie transports you to that time in a way I've never felt a movie do before. I've literally watched it over 50 times and always find something new and interesting. It's beautiful even while being violent, a very difficult thing to do. It's also very funny, in a wry way, without losing any dramatical punch.I don't often give a 10 but this is worth it on every level!

Warning:  100% Spoilers aheadThis film gets better every time you see it and IMHO the finest Cohen film out there. Anyone who thinks this film is second rate simply doesn't understand it...and it is hard to follow the first time around which is a justifiable criticism (for example, the first time I saw it I had no idea that there was a huge homosexual subplot to the story).
This movie involves a gang war during the Prohibition era between the entrenched Irish mob and the growing Italian mob, with a sleazy bookie (who is homosexual and Jewish) caught in the middle.  You will never see a more brilliant performance by Byrne or Turtorro and Harden is fantastic as well.
Comparing it to the Godfather is accurate, because both are romanticized versions of the mafia (e.g., handsome mafia dons in tuxes and machine guns). A comparison to Goodfellas is silly, which portrays a more stark and gritty view of mafia life with ugly people in ugly clothes getting addicted to drugs, and therefore totally different in character.  There are many homages to Godfather throughout, the most obvious is the opening scene:  both involve a bald, mustached italian man coming to the godfather to ask for a murder.  The second most obvious is at the very end, right when Tom is walking up to his apartment after setting up the final killing and a TRAIN runs by (even though it is 4:00 AM), an homage to the scene in Godfather I when the train goes by and Michael wacks Salazzo and the Police Captain.
Stylistically, it doesn't get any better than this with simply gorgeous camera work panning over the shoes, the clothes, the cars of the era.
The triangles of love betrayals exist on every level:  Tom betrays Leo, through his affair with Myrnah.  Myrnah betrays Leo, through her affair with Tom.  Tom betrays Myrnah, by almost wacking Bernie the first time.  Mink betrays Dane, by his affair with Bernie.  Who among the principal characters remains "true"?  Caspar.  So Caspar's funny talk about ethics, which most write off as humorous dialogue, is central to the issue of moral code in this film.

I've never seen a bad coen brothers' film and at this time this is their best.labyrinthine plot which rewards repeat viewing, it is at once a great homage and a great gangster film, a difficult path to walk.Perfect Dialogue, perfect performances, beautiful sets and marvelous costumes coupled with fantastic cinematography and if all that wasn't enough the oft repeated score of Carter Burwell takes this film into a level of perfection that I thought was nearly impossible.Some may gripe, but very few, and if they do you can just ignore them- This is the greatest.

This movie doesn't quite have the prestige of other gangster films such as the Godfathers or Goodfellas, in many respects, it is just as good.  I know it's a bold statement to mention a little-known film like Miller's Crossing with such classics, but it is really a great film.  The dialogue is terrific, although some people I know seem to think it's a little cheesy. The story is both wonderfully told and filmed.  The most memorable scene from the film, in my opinion, is when Tom is walking Bernie into the woods. Never before have I seen the dilemma of taking a man's life so well portrayed.  I would recommend any fan of gangster films, the Coen brothers, or film in general to see this movie.

One of my favorites. I really can't add much to the glowing reviews previously posted - this is a perfect movie. I feel very sorry for the people who see the film as slow or boring – the script is perfection, the imagery sublime and the casting/acting as dead-on as I have ever seen. Perhaps these dissenters just don't get the whole stoic Irish thing.there is a world spinning in Gabriel Byrne's eyes in every scene – if you can't see that wellI can't help you.Tom Regan is a perfect tragic hero – a man who triumphs via his analytical machinations and at the same time loses everything emotionally. I have always read it that he did love Verna; you can see it in Gabriel Byrnes subtle acting and in the willingness of his character to keep seeing her. He is fighting his reason and lying to himself about his level of detachment in having even started the affair with her. Tom sees love as a weakness and sacrifices it. At the end he has won - but really, all he has left is his hat and his cunning.That this came out of writers block on Barton Fink..gotta love the Coens.

For a decade and a half the debate has raged whether "Godfather" or "Goodfellas" is the greatest of the multitude of modern mob movies. My two cents has always been that they are equally good, distinct, works of art but that "Miller's Crossing" belongs in the conversation as well. Released three days after Goodfellas in Sept. '90, MC happens to be the best script of the three, sorry Mario, and while it can't match the sheer verite' thrill of a Deniro Pesci improv, the Hammettesque dialog transports you to another place entirely. Godfather's style is equaled as is the (GASP) cast. Finney-Brando (edge to Brando) Byrne-Pacino(edge Pacino), Keaton-Gay Harden (edge Gay Harden) Polito-Duvall (pick-em), Cazale-Turturro (edge Cazale), Caan-Freeman (edge to Caan).. Close calls most of them and tough to judge since stylistically they're doing very different things. All three bear the voice of the artists that made them. That's what makes them great. All three.

`Friendship, Character. Ethics'. Where to start? We're talking favourite movies here folks so only superlatives will do. On the surface, this is the usual Cohen fare: rapid-fire dialogue, camera swoops and twirls, invention and subversion. What separates this wheat from theemother wheat of the brothers' output is the potent love-triangle (a much-abused phrase I admit) that glues the explosive theatrics together. Tom and Verna, Verna and Leo, Tom and Leo? There's love here pilgrims, real love, though the principals can't bring themselves to utter the word.What of the performances? Well, Mr. Byrne ambles his way through one of the most wonderfully laconic performances since Jimmy Stewart kissed goodbye to the silver screen. Attention, breast-beating METHOD actorsthis is cinema, deliciously underplayed. Marcia Gay Harden matches Tom/Gabriel step for jaded step, and Albert Finney shines as the (dangerous) boob in the middle. And hats off to Carter Burwell for his delightful appropriation of Lament for Limerick'. Recommendedin case you haven't guessed..

Ummm... My tape is done. I have watched this movie so much the video tape couldn`t bear it anymore. And I am sick now. I have to get Miller`s Crossing NOW!!!Does anybody said Don Corleone? Tommy would surely kick his ass?See, how sick am I about this movie? :)

'Miller's Crossing' is a captivating story, brewed slowly but ever so sweet to taste once the plot thickens. A truly wonderful masterpiece that leaves 'Godfather' riddled with bullets in comparison. Unfortunately it failed to inspire similar cult following due to its lack of strong character. Don't get me wrong, the performances were magnificient, but other than Casper the rest of the characters were quite dull and unlovable. That 'Irish' charm is missing in the Mob and the Mafia didn't even seem Italian. I guess if you had mixed 'miller's' plot with 'godfather's' class and character you'd get the best movie ever conceived. Anyway, I enjoyed this more than 'the Godfather'.Just a suggestion: In the end of the movie when Bernie pleads to Tom to look into his heart, Tommy should have replied something like 'Not today' instead of 'what heart'. That would have captured the impulsive nature of the storyline. That much like anyone else, a gangster will make decisions based on impulses at the time.

So much has been said of this film already. Yes, I am a Coen fan. Yes, this is the best Movie of all time. But to merely consider it a Gangster Pic - to then cast a thought (or even comparison -  heaven forbid) back to the Godfathers or Goodfellas does not give this film its just desserts. Miller's is meticulous in detail - from design through to the lip-dripping dialogue. It is such an obvious labour of love for all involved - the casting of Gabriel Byrne, Albert Finney, Jon Polito, John Turturro all perfect; like classical theatre, but even better. The music by Carter Burwell brings tears to my ears!?! Shakespeare could not have written a better study of conniving doublecross and tragedy!Go COEN go!

reviews.review_title: The worst movie I have ever seen
reviews.content: Thought I'd try to catch up with some of the Coen Brothers earlier movies I haven't already seen 100 times. So I wasted money on this. My gripes : A terrible script. Mostly incomprehensible. Names are reeled out - too much diifficult to follow dialogue. Scenes mostly dark. I had no clear idea of who is who and what is going on. Ridiculous fight scenes. Silly smoke effects from machine guns. Huge amounts of gratuitous killing. Byrne mumbling and looking blank most of the time, with bizarre changing accents. A tedious and most unentertaining and unpleasant movie. This a masterpiece of utter rubbish. Saw it through to the end but none the wiser. Just annoyed. Should have switched it off much earlier. Only John Turturro and Jon Polito were acting properly. Maybe it is supposed to be a comedy. If so it is in totally bad taste. There are no saving graces.

I'd agree with another reviewer on this site that this is a great film, although I would not go so far as to suggest (as he does) that it's the best film ever made. It would definitely be in my top twenty, but maybe not in my top ten. Whichever way you dice it, though, this is a superbly crafted film, well written, well directed and well acted.Thank heavens that there are people out there like these brothers who are prepared to make intelligent, creative, thought-provoking films as opposed to the formulaic rubbish coming out of the big studios. Apart from this film, I would also commend "Fargo", "Barton Fink" and "The Hudsucker Proxy" (but see the Cary Grant version of "The Front Page" first, or you won't appreciate a great take-off by a great actress).
For some reason I had put off watching this film for 25 years. Just watched it and it's great! Some briliant characters involved in a great plot. Don't make my mistakes and watch straight away.

reviews.review_title: get this and all other coen brother's movies if you like film
reviews.content: a great dashiel hammet spoof, this movie. and a splendid drinking game. this film contains my very favorite performance by indie darling john tutorro and one of my favorites from gabriel byrne. look for cameos by tons of fringe and or indie personalities, including sam raimi (evil dead, army of darkness). "Jesus, Tom."

reviews.review_title: The Coen's best, and the genre's
reviews.content: My Top Five Movies list is constantly changing, but Miller's Crossing has never fallen off.  It is very nearly a perfect film.At this point, the gangster film genre is completely hackneyed, but somehow the entire movie feels fresh and vital.  Everything -- the characters, dialogue, acting, cinematography, direction -- is highly stylized and lovingly deliberate. Every shot would make a good framed photo, and every line of dialogue is quotable.Yes, everything here has been done before, but the brilliance of Miller's Crossing is that it distills, with obvious love and stunning talent, the essence of the genre.  You must see this movie.

reviews.review_title: It wasn't bad but it was alright
reviews.content: Personally I enjoyed the film however it felt like it was missing so much. The one major action scene made every other action feel lacklustre in comparison. I enjoyed the story however I saw most of the twists and turns coming a mile away with the exception to two or three. My only other issue with the film is that sometimes it sounds like the actors forget their accents and vary between an Irish and New York mobster accent.

Very interesting one by Coen brothers, the characters are good so does the script, this movie can teach you how to think smart, actually WISE.I enjoyed the movie after I caught up with every angle and edge in the story, It Is a bit complex, still worth all his lenght.With some stronger frames and a slightly different pace It really could have been a masterpiece.

Yes, it is. Seriously, this movie is right up there with flicks like "Casablanca", as one of the best movies ever made and one you can enjoy watching over and over. (I DON'T generally re-watch movies, but I've probably watched "Millers Crossing" at least 7 or 8 times.)Script - PERFECT. The 1920s/30s underworld slang is wonderfully entertaining. The script is just one witty line after another, many of them delivered perfectly by Gabriel Byrne. On the one hand, it's one of the darkest movies ever - yet it never ceases being relentlessly funny: At one point, Jon Polito's character says to Tom (Byrne) that he's only going to tell him something if Tom PROMISES not to say, "I told you so"...Tom, with a deadly serious frown on his face, gesturing with his cigarette for emphasis, assures him, "I never say that - and I don't like people who do."...Polito tells what he has to relate...there's a perfect half-second pause...and then Tom casually drawls, "I told you so." :)Acting - EVERYBODY is awesome (outstanding Albert Finney performance)...but Byrne still manages to steal the show. I think it's easily his best movie ever - (yes, even better than his awesome performance in "The Usual Suspects"). His Irish accent is like listening to great music, and he's got so many great lines - like after he's lost $500 betting on a horse that broke its leg coming down the home stretch of the track, and the bartender asks, "Did they shoot your horse, Tom?" - Byrne growls his disgusted reply, "If there's any justice."Cinematography/Production Design - It's a beautiful movie to watch. The alternately swanky and drab interiors are all works of art, and a late night scene in the rain is nothing short of a cinematic masterpiece.Editing/Directing - The Coen brothers have never done anything better than this. Every scene, every line, every shot is just flat out perfect.If you haven't seen this flick, do yourself a huge favor and go grab it right now. - That's another thing that tells you how good this movie is - I've never met anybody who didn't like it - didn't LOVE it.

reviews.review_title: Still excellent after all these years
reviews.content: One of my favorite Cohen-brothers movie and definitely on the Top Ten-list.'Miller's Crossing' captures the romanticized, depression-era mobster and the film-noir ethics and aesthetics spot on and is just simply beautiful to watch.The way the Cohen brothers lovingly portray their lead characters is something I haven't seen in a long time. Their clever plot twists and, above all, John Turturro's devilish, deceiving character are amazing. Miller's Crossing is an interesting companion piece to Barton Fink and is worth watching as a double-feature.

I love all the coen bros's films except raising arizona and Barton Fink which i don't get but this is their best film in my opinion, it's very complex and needs repeat viewings to get the best out of it.But it's great the way they deal with ethics,it's very funny at times (nearly all the scenes with John Polito are hilarious)I won't bother talking about the plot,just to say if you like movies to use you're brain and you like comedy you'll love this.Plus is Tom in love with Leo or Verna

reviews.review_title: The proof of the excellent Coen Brothers work in every genre.
reviews.content: Here we are, a gangsters movie by the Coen Brothers?? Yep, At first look, It seems strange from the Coen Brothers to do this kind of movie. But every films genre that the Coen Brothers make It turns into a gold work.First: The casting, I don't very like Gabriel Byrne's acting but this time he surprised me, in the role of Tom Reagan he made the difference. Jon Polito, John Turturro (in the role of a Jewish gangster was good as usually), J.E Freeman, Steve Buscemi(It's almost a cameo, he appeared in one scene and die again in this film) and finally the great Albert Finney plays in this film too. He's "the guest-star" of this film, he's pretty terrific in the role of Leo.The Story : I was a little disappointed (just a little) by the script I was expected a more complex story, but The Coen Brothers I think have a best written with Comedy Script even if there are funny dialogues. Some scenes remind me some gangsters films, The Coens certainly wanted to make a homage of the classic gangsters films.The directing is again excellent with this time more poetic and slowly shots (The "hat shot" is beautiful) to show the drama feeling of the film cause 70% part of the film is drama, the other 30% are Action and Comedy situations.So, to resume It's again an excellent film By the Coens. You're genius guys!!

Let me first start out by saying that I am a huge Coen Brothers fan. I have yet to see a film of theirs I truly disliked. There have been a few that were not up to par, but the movies weren't horrible. This is my third favorite Coens film. The acting in this is brilliant, Gabriel Byrne is by far the best. The way he plays the character, and the way the Coens have written it, you never know what he'll do next, and it will always surprise you. Jon Polito gives a terrific performance as Johnny Caspar. The scenes with his son are hysterical. But what I think I like most about the film is that is really isn't a gangster movie, it focuses more on emotions and the way people feel for each other. Whether it be Leo's love for Verna, or the double-crossing that happens throughout the movie, and the emotional strains it puts on the characters. This being my first review, it may not sound great, but believe this. You won't be disappointed by this film if you are a fan of film.

reviews.review_title: Infectiously humorous! Never a dull moment:
reviews.content: This movie, was so infectiously funny, words alone could not express the joy I had watching this movie. The Coen Brothers(Joel & Ethan) never cease to amaze people like me. This movie is worth seeing. This is by far, one very well done movie, with lots of thriller content and quite a few "one-liners". I definitely can appreciate the kind of film-making the Coen Brothers do, as they look at different angles during the process of the movie making. I am glad to see such creativity of characters they brothers conjure up. Miller's Crossing is definitely one of those movies, I would gladly shell out some hard-earned money & buy it outright. I don't really know if there is much more I can write except one has to see the movie. It was hilarious!!!

I hardly watch any movies more than once, but "Miller's Crossing" draws some of its intrigue from the main character's ambiguous intentions. Each time I watch it I keep looking for clues as to when Joe changes his mind. Who can keep their eyes off Gabriel Byrne here?It's a high compliment that with the sheer volume of movies from the U.S. and abroad available today, this one has left an unforgettable imprint on my mind over the years. Hardly any Coen brothers' film fails to leave an impression. It's hard to forget a film where the main character gets beaten up a few times, loses his best friend, and loses the girl, but wins the peace.Definitely a favourite.

The film is technically sound like all others of their films and looks great throughout. It is both 50s and 90s at the same time. Or, was it 40s. The characters are interesting. The protagonist is very charismatic, the character and the actor. Too little drama, for my liking. Also William Macy was in the movie for a brief while who played a major role in Fargo. The whole double crossing game became boring at some point. The noir style was very appealing, including lighting, shadows, movement. Scene in Caspers place was my favorite. The use of Miller's Crossing as a crucial part of movie justified the movie title and also rendered character to the place.

In my opinion this is probably the most perfect piece of cinema ever created. A complete and utter masterpiece. There's not a single bad shot in the entire film. Every character is beautifully created and every scene is pure eye-candy. The only two films to come close to the perfection of Miller's Crossing are Grosse Point Blank and The Shawshank Redemption. The Coen's greatest work by far. Hire this film out tonight!

Miller's Crossing is not a direct adaptation of any single Hammett novel, but it borrows liberally from the plots of Red Harvest and The Glass Key. The result is a movie more faithful to the spirit of Dashiell Hammett's work than most direct Hammett adaptations.  Miller's Crossing joins Yojimbo (adapted loosely from Red Harvest) and Hammett (in which the author is protagonist) as the best non-Hammett Hammett movies.

reviews.review_title: I watch this movie once a month
reviews.content: There's nothing more foolish than a man chasing his hat - except anyone who misses this film.  Fred McMurray, now lying in his grave, wishes he had done Double Indemnity the way Gabriel Byrne does Miller's crossing.  Forget every film noir gangster film you've ever seen.  The Coen brothers stand on the summit of that genre with this masterpiece of violence, irreverent humor, and the best shot ever made of a decomposed body lying in the woods, heightened only by the laughter of Tick-Tack.

At the risk of sounding like everybody else who has commented on this film, I think this film represents movie making at its best. I love the way the "bad" guys in this movie tend to tell the truth and indeed are primarily concerned with "ethics". Visually this film is stunning.  From little details like the shine on a gangsters shoe as he puts out a cigarette to the scene that can only be described as loving depiction of Thompson artistry - this movie is frame by frame gorgeous. In the Big Sleep when Lauren Becall first meets Humphrey Bogart she tells him he's not very tall to which Bogey replies "I try to be".  I'm pretty sure W. Faulkner wrote that dialogue, which in my opinion has nothing on the dialogue in Millers Crossing. Come to think of it- wasn't the guy Bogey was hired to find in the Big Sleep named Tom Regan?

Coming home drunk one night, I found myself looking for some low rent entertainment on my fancy, new cable box. I found a forgotten classic in "Miller's Crossing." I find it incredible that the Coen Brothers are not more recognized for their contribution to American cinema,particularly this movie. Not as flashy as Tarantino, not as epic as Spielberg, the Coen Brothers are flat-out interesting.It escapes me why the IMDb Top 250 doesn't include this movie. "Children of Men?" "Batman Begins?" These are top 250 films that I love. I don't want to say that the United States makes the best movies, but if anybody knows of an obscure, non-American film maker with the inspiration of the Coen's, please tell me.That having been said, do yourself a favor and watch "Miller's Crossing" again. Please see the beauty of the story and, of course, Turturro's scene in the woods. It is one of the best ever filmed. I am not being arrogant in saying these things. I just want somebody to see the beauty in this movie that I see.

This film gets high marks from me for its rewatchability. The first time I saw it I wasn't that impressed because the plot was hard to follow and the main character's motivations were unclear. But everything improves on a second viewing (and a third...). The plot is one of the most complex and rewarding that I have seen in any film or novel. The main character Tom is very contradictory. He is good but unlucky. He knows everything except how to make himself happy.Marcia Gay Harden has her character down to even the slightest head tilting. As Gabriel Byrne says on the DVD-extra, it is so refreshing to see a story driven by a female.

reviews.review_title: My personal favorite from the Coen Brothers.
reviews.content: Miller's Crossing appears in the guise of a mobster film, but it is a very clever parody of mobster films.  It uses the genre to portray in an endearing manner the several themes that are constants of the Coen Brothers -- Crime doesn't pay.  Violence doesn't solve anything.  Deceit collapses on itself.  Cleverness is only useful when it is not self-centered.  People are frail and prone to evil, but are capable of surprising goodness.  Miller's Crossing is my personal favorite from the Coen the Brothers.Coen Brother films divide into two categories:  Dark Films with comic undertones (like this one and Fargo), and Comic Films with dark undertones (like Raising Arizona and O Brother Where Art Thou?).  One or two split the middle (like The Big Lebowski).  Miller's Crossing is definitely as dark as they come, but it is also mystifying, witty, enchanting, alluring, and yes, even romantic in a weird way.Okay, it draws character traits and some one-liners from one or more Dash Hammett novel (which I also enjoy), but this is also a wonderfully creative, memorable, and (aside from the Hammett borrowings) original work.I give it a "9."  I would give it a "10," but then what would I give to the Coen Brother film that someday tops this one?

The reason why this movie isn't recognized as one of the greatest gangster pictures is probably due to it being too hard to follow, and too funny. In the end I think it is a dead-pan comedy with good, dramatic bits, like most Coen films in my opinion. But it is a very nice watch: beautifully shot, great acting, lots of jokes and with flawless pacing. I wouldn't mind re-watching it to get an idea exactly what's it about.

I watched Miller's Crossing before I ever saw The Godfather (1+2). The comparison between the two is frankly apples to oranges in terms of film making and artistic intention. If a gun were held to my head, I might say The Godfather's are better films. I might say relationships between characters are more thoroughly flushed out. I might say that it even presents more cinematographic eye candy... But I LIKE Miller's Crossing. It breaks every rule The Godfather established. Miller's Crossing shocked me in my first viewing. It made me laugh. It made me cry. It treads upon a line of surrealistic flavors. But as for the movie itself: Tom is one of the best characters in cinema history. His character is sly, cunning, douchey, scummy, and still lovable. The supporting cast each fills their role perfectly. The Coen Brothers have crafted a bizarre and oh so slightly absurd masterpiece with this film. But most importantly, perhaps, they showed us a film with a heart, with charisma, and with intention.

reviews.review_title: Gabriel Byrne delivers a standout performance!
reviews.content: "Miller's Crossing" might not be the best mob drama ever produced - for my money, nothing tops "The Godfather" - but it is an impressive film nonetheless.  Gabriel Byrne is masterful as Tom, a relatively sane man in an otherwise insane business.  His performance and a stirring soundtrack make this a film that is not to be missed!

reviews.review_title: Gangster movies taken to unique Coen Brothers perfection
reviews.content: This film throws you from heart-attack inducing plot twist to breathtaking cliffhanger so many times it's hard to keep track, but somehow you do. The Coen Brothers' finest moment. Quite how this film got to be made is beyond me, it is perfect in every respect and John Turturro's performance is just amazing. When I grow up (if 24 isn't already grown up) I want to be Tom - super cool, knows the angles and fiercely independent. Beyond brilliant.
Interesting movie. A good and well thought script, hard to follow on moments. A bit slow on times.7/10

reviews.review_title: The most perfect film I've had the pleasure of watching.
reviews.content: Every performance and every shot in this movie is fantastic.  Not a hair out of place.  The entire film seems surreal and treats its main characters like some kind of mob deities.  They don't die by accident or from the attacks of lesser beings.  They can only destroy each other.  Albert Finney, Joe Polito, and Gabriel Byrne are phenomenal.

reviews.review_title: Best of the Coen's many great films
reviews.content: From the opening sequence which mimics "The Godfather", this movie is just about perfect.  Gabriel Byrne is wonderful as Tom Reagan, and quite frankly so are all the other performers in their roles.  Albert Finney should have been nominated for an Oscar as should have Jon Polito for his amazing turn as Johnny Caspar.  The look, the feel, the dialogue are all top-notch.

reviews.review_title: The movie which made me 'fall in love' with cinema
reviews.content: One of the few movies I've seen again and again.Perfect. If only the Coen Bros. would give up on the comedies.... (except for Barton Fink - that's a 10).This is a flawless movie - now see 'Blood Simple' for the foundations of their brilliant filmmaking.

reviews.review_title: a masterpiece of loyalty and betrayal
reviews.content: The Coen brothers are quietly the best filmakers working today.  This film is the best example of what they're capable of in a body of work that is unprecedented amongst their peers.  Gabriel Byrne delivers the role he was born to play.  The story focuses on Byrne's friendship with Finney's character and the illicit affection  he has with Finney's love interest, Hardin.  Torturro as Hardin's brother steals every scene he is in.The film is beautiful to watch with some of the most intellegent symbolism ever captured in a mainstream picture.  Impossible to predict and filled with the always intelligent Coen dialogue, this movie demands multiple viewings and stays with the audience long after the conclusion.

reviews.review_title: One of the five best movies I have ever seen...
reviews.content: With all of the intricate plot twists, compelling characters, clever dialogue and great acting, this movie is one of the finest I have seen. This is the best Coen brothers movie, which says a lot. I hope they come out with it in DVD.This also has cameo appearances from other Coen brothers regulars.

This film has become one of my favorite gangster films. It has all the hallmarks of a good film: a great cast, a plot that keeps one intrigued, beautiful cinematography, and first-rate editing. However, it becomes a great film because of how it portrays the complexity of the human experience. It's a film that should be watched many times, not just for the pleasure of the acting and how it flows, but because it makes one deeply think more deeply about human virtues. Can a criminal have virtues? In a simplistic world view in which things are either black or white, good or bad, one would have to say no. But this film challenges this notion and sees the contradictions inherent in our humanity. Tom Reagan (Gabriel Byrne) is a criminal, a gangster, yet in spite of that, he has a strong sense of ethics and this film is largely how this man maintains his ethics in a world that is not. There is a consistent sense of justice in how this character acts, even if it is not apparent at first. It is in the play of what society considers ethical behavior to be and what it is in an unethical situation that is at the heart of this film.

reviews.review_title: A Fat Bubble of Sophistication, A sea of gangsters and harboring policemen
reviews.content: It's so sophisticated, complex and I didn't really understood the value of this film, it's a shattered mess and I feel like it needs more respect to the direction. It's A gritty film but I want to give positive points because the screenplay and scripting is more accurate than "The Untouchables". I can't really relate The Coen Brothers films because they are so sophisticated and gritty, but in all seriousness though I'm satisfied with their movies' plots.Please forgive me for the wrong grammar if I made any, I'm a filipino.

This, to me, is one of the best gangster movies of all time, percise in every aspect. The quotes in this movie are endless, and some of the scenes you see in "Miller's Crossing" will live in your memory forever. The attention to detail is mesmerizing, what else can I say ..... 10/10

Well, this is one of those rare gems of a movie that everyone should see, and I have little to add to the several excellent reviews of it already given here  but let me just say I think it is simply a flawless film in every respect: story, camera work, acting, milieu, dialogue, music, rhythm, mood  you can watch it any number of times and still (like a good piece of music, or like some other of the Coen brothers's movies) derive even more pleasure from it. And even so, once you think you've penetrated the multi-layered cinematographic "surface" of this story, you will find that it's actually very far from an allegedly postmodern rip-off of gangster movies and novels from the 40's (although it uses Hammett in particular to great effect): below the slick surface there's an intricate psychological  indeed a psychoanalytical drama in disguise  being played out, the complexities of which may take you the better part of your life to work out. What is intriguing about it, not least, is the way the plot seems impossible to work out, at least from Tom Reagan's point of view: as he asks to his boss Leo, at the end, "do you always know why you do things"? Leo says sure he does  but Tom, obviously, just like this viewer remains very unsure of why he acts as he does

reviews.review_title: Ambiguity is a great film's trademark
reviews.content: Miller's Crossing is one of my absolute favorites. As many Coen brothers' movies, it is a remake. A quite accurate remake of a 1942 Alan Ladd-flick the Glass Key, a good film on its own based on a Dashiel Hammett's story. This is the kind of material the Coen brothers like to start with to add their unique spin.I just watched the movie about the 18th time and I will not bother you about the plot (I'm not expecting to get a top position, so you probably already know it). Suffice it to say it is complicated, and as always, again I found something new.This time it was the homosexual aspect. There is a strong connotation. Dane for one is in love with Mink, who is enticed by Bernie who takes the advantage on him to place good bets. Bernie is a bisexual, incestuous (by his own confession) manipulator and a most repulsive character but still the protagonist Tommy-boy gives him a break, once. "Look into your heart!" Finallly he kills him, but even then somewhat reluctantly. In the final cut Tom takes a long heartbreaking look... not for Verna, who left the scene already... but for Leo! So what if it was all about Tom being secretly in love with Leo? That would explain some of his moves pretty well, wouldn't it? For instance at some point he had the opportunity of fleeing with Verna which he didn't use. As others have pointed out, it was also a bit unclear why exactly he had to kill Bernie, unless it was a crime of passion. In my humble eighteenth opinion it all makes sense only if Tom's ultimate motive at all times was just to protect Leo's feelings.Not to mention the fact that the single clearly heterosexual character in the whole film, Johny Caspar with his ethos of bringing up a family is somewhat ridiculed. Or the slightly masculine appearance of Verna.Well, this is only one reading of the film and quite possibly wrong. At least if the creators went for a single right purpose. Don't think they did.
